courses.title: Acroyoga Open House
courses.description: A curriculum for the acroyoga open house.

lessons.title: Movement Exploration
lessons.synopsis: Get into your body and develop fluidity
lessons.instructions:
On hands-and-knees explore shoulder movements:
- Shoulder push-ups
- Shoulder circles
- Unilateral shoulder circles
- Find your own shoulder/upper body movements

lessons.title: Plank Play
lessons.synopsis: Learn the principle: "The flyer holds the shape. The base balances."
lessons.instructions: One person goes into the top of push-up. The other person lifts the ankles. Drop one ankle at a time. The person on the ground has to keep the ankles together.

lessons.title: Leg tosses
lessons.synopsis: Connect the back to the ground for stability
lessons.instructions: One person lies on the back and raises their legs straight up. The other person tosses the legs left, right, forward, and back. The first person resists.

lessons.title: Cross Forearms on Legs
lessons.synopsis: Learn bone stacking
lessons.instructions: One person lies on their back and raises the legs straight up. The other person crosses the forearms in front of the chest. The other person places the forearms on the base's feet and adds their whole weight.

lessons.title: Hammock
lessons.synopsis: The easiest way to get into the air
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back with the shins up.
2. The flyer sits on the base's knees, facing away.
3. The base puts their feet behind the flyer's knee pits.
4. The flyer leans back until the flyer's shoulderblades rest on top of the base's hands.
5. The base straightens their legs.

lessons.title: "Table on Table"
lessons.synopsis: Learn bone stacking
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back with the knees on top of the hips and the arms on top of the shoulders.
2. The flyer places their palms on the shins of the base just below the kneecap.
3. The flyer places the first knee (same position as above) on top of the base's dominant hand.
4. The flyer slowly shifts the weight to lift the second leg onto the other base's hands.

The pair can now "walk," extend arms/legs at the same time, or open the knees/arms outside.

lessons.title: Bird Receiving
lessons.synopsis: Prepare for bird pose
lessons.instructions:
Important! Take your time to really receive well and controlled and for the flyer to maintain a plank throughout the movement.

1. The base puts their arms down along the side. The flyer walks up so that flyer toes meet the base's fingertips.

2. The base places the feet on the flyers hips. The middle of the balls of the feet should meet the pointy part of the hip bone.

3. The flyer maintains the plank pose while the base bends their knees.

- Bend the knees slowly to avoid scaring the flyer.
- Go progressively deeper.
- Practice controlling the speed and stopping point.

lessons.title: Bird Pose
lessons.synopsis: Learn the quintessential acroyoga pose
lessons.instructions:
1. Start with bird receiving.
2. Receive until the "hook point." That's when the base feels like they have the entire weight of the flyer.
3. The base scoops up the flyer into the air.

Focus on straight arms and legs!

lessons.title: King Throne aka Chair
lessons.synopsis: Feel like a Queen!
lessons.instructions:
1. The flyer stands with their feet next to the base's ears, facing away.

2. The base places their toes right below the butt on the thigh.

3. The flyer leans back until the "hook point" (the base feels the flyer's full weight on them).

4. The base presses the flyer up until the legs are stacked and the arms are stacked under the flyer's feet.

5. To come down, transition the hands back to the ankles. Be sure to let go off the flyer once on the ground to avoid tripping them.

lessons.title: High-Flying Whale
lessons.synopsis: A fun restorative pose
lessons.instructions:
1. The flyer places their feet next to the ears of the base, facing away.

2. The base reaches with their toes to the bra strap/heart rate monitor level on the flyer's back.

3. The flyer leans back.

4. The base graps the flyer's ankles and pushes them up on their feet.

5. Ask the flyer for a preferred foot angle to control the amount of back stretch.

Note: The stacked position in this pose is more like a suspension bridge. The arms and legs of the base are straight, but facing a bit away from each other.

lessons.title: Movement Exploration: Quadrupet Position
lessons.synopsis: A warm-up that replaces mechanical repetition with curiosity, teaching the body to move smarter
lessons.instructions:
Goal:
Develop a greater range, control, and creativity in how the body moves - building adaptibility and awareness that will directly increase success in learning acroyoga.

Instructions:
1. Assume quadrupet position (on hands an knees).
2. Remain within the scope of shoulder movements. Explore different movements that you fill drawn to or your body needs. Feel free to speed up, slow down, enlarge movements, and discover your own.

Here are some ideas to get started:
- Do shoulder circles: one side, both sides, opposite direction.
- Make them larger by dropping an elbow and even larger by twisting the torso.
- Focus on shrugging the shoulders up and down.
- Do shoulder blad push-ups.
- Shift side-to-side.
- Add cat/cow (spinal flexing and extending).

lessons.title: Movement Exploration: Half kneeling
lessons.synopsis: Expands hip mobility and control through guided half-kneeling exploration.
lessons.instructions:
1. Kneel with one leg. (Like a lunge with the back knee down and both knees at 90 degrees.)
2. Move the back shin perpedicular to the lunge. (This will create stability for the movement.)
3. Explore hip movements.

Here are some ideas to get started:
- Shift forward and backward.
- Shift side-to-side.
- Do hip circles.
- Allow the hip to tilt in different ways.
- Face to the side, forward, and to the opposite side as far as you can.
- Include the torso by leaning forward/back, twisting, and so on.

lessons.title: Movement Exploration: L-Sit
lessons.synopsis: Explores core activation and shoulder engagement in the L-sit, building control, compression strength, and awareness of how the body balances between lift and support.
lessons.instructions:
1. Sit with the legs straight in front and hands at the side with palms on the floor.
2. Press into the hands to lift the butt off the ground. This will include contracting the core.

Here are ideas for movement exploration:
- Swing the hips back and forth.
- Use the shoulders and arms to push higher/lower.
- Lean with the shoulders backwards and forwards.
- Walk the feet forward and back.
- Shift side-to-side.
- Try to twist the body.
- Try to lift the feet off the ground.
- Take off one hand to hover.

lessons.title: Drill: Wheelbarrow Hold
lessons.synopsis: A drill to introduce the concept of tightness
lessons.instructions:
Goal: Introduces and trains the concept of tightness for flyers

Instructions:
1. One person assumes top of a push-up (plank position).
2. The supporting partner lifts the other person's ankles up.
3. The trainee locks in the body position.
4. The supporting partner lets go of one leg while the trainee has to keep the body position locked in (feet next to teach other).

Note:---
The supporting person should start with easy challenges and increase them as the trainee can handle them. The idea is to find the sweet spot of strong challenge without hurting the trainee.

Variations:---
- Start by squeezing the ankle first before letting go. That signals the trainee to pepare themselves.
- As they get better, skip the signal. As they get better, pick the next leg without signaling.
- Make sequence of left and right unpredictable.
- Change up the timing.
- Increase the speed of letting go.
- Fake out letting go off one leg, aborting, and then letting go.
- Pushing the feet and by extension the whole body forward requires the trainee to stabilize with the arms by pushing back.

Principle:---
In acro yoga, there are principles like "Tight is light." and "The flyer holds the shape. The base balances."

Tightness and holding the shape means that the flyer makes a rigid shape by tensing their body.

This is critical because it's hard to balance a wobbly shape. Also if both the base and flyer balance, each other's body movements are going to fight each other. Thus the division of responsibility is that the flyer makes a tight shape and the base does the entire job of balancing.

Also in higher level acro where flyers are thrown through the air, this is important. For example, if a throw goes wrong, the flyer should turn themselves into a stick (= tight, rigid body). That gives the base and spotters a chance to get a hold of the flyer's body to catch them before they land on the floor.
graduationRequirements: Can hold the feet parallel.
Can handle unexpected letting go.
Can handle faking out.
Can handle pushing forward/back.

lessons.title: Drill: Partner Pushups (Bonestacking)
lessons.synopsis: Use the partner pushup position to learn bone stacking
lessons.instructions:
Starting Position:
One person lies on their back and extends the arms up. The other person assumes the top of a push-up position on top of the hands of the lying person.

Phase 1: Explore Bone Stacking
In the first phase of the exercise, we explore bone stacking (explained below). Try bending the arms, moving the arms left and right, and so on. The goal is to explore in which direction it becomes harder and to find the easiest arm alignment to hold.

The easiest arm alignment should be when both people's arms are straight and form a direct line between the two people's shoulders.


Phase 2: Do push-ups
In the second phase, we do push-ups to become familiar with the dynamic movement of how the bonestack is affected.

Start by taking turns of only one partner doing push-ups.

Then do push-ups at the same time.


Phase 3: Hold for the Longest Time
In the third phase, we try to hold this position for the longest time. Your arms should be tired from the push-ups, which is by design. It'll naturally motivate you to find the arm position, which is easiest to hold. And that should be when the bones are stacked well.

Tip: If it seems like you can hold this easily forever, walk the feet away from the partner. The lower angle should provide more challenge.

Concept: Bone Stacking:---
Bone stacking is one of those key techniques in acroyoga why casual people copying instagram videos fail spectacularly and trained people easily succeed.

A great way to illustrate the concept is to bring two body positions to mind: Picture yourself standing at a subway platform, waiting for the train. You probably assume a position that will make it easy to stand for a long time. Then picture yourself doing chair pose in yoga (i.e. sitting on an imaginary chair).

Many people hate chair pose because it becomes very uncomfortable very quickly. The reason is that it takes a lot of muscle to hold the position. On the other hand, standing on the subway, one usually stands pretty straight. When the legs are straight, the bones carry most of the weight.

So bonestacking is the practice of aligning the bones on top of each other to carry the weight (e.g. straight elbows and knees).

The shortcut is that legs and arms should be straight up to the ceiling. That's corect most of the time.

The more correct way is that the bones should make a direct line between the two points. For example with the parner push-up exercise, we've seen that it's actually not vertical but a direct line between the shoulders.

Tip: Sometimes, people (especially "gym bros") believe that to lift someone, they have to be very strong. So they bend their elbows/knees so that they can tense all their muscles more. Yeah, it does make them feel stronger. However, it burns a lot of energy. They can support much more weight by keeping their arms/legs straight.

lessons.title: Drill: Pilates Leg Circles
lessons.synopsis: An exercise borrowed from pilates to develop core stability for basing
lessons.instructions:
1. Lie flat on the back.
2. Raise one leg to 90 degrees.
3. Make small circles with the leg in the air. The key is to keep the torso still on the ground.

Purpose:---
This exercise develops core stability. The torso doesn't stay still be simply constant tightness, but the core tension has to consistently adjust.

Doing this for the first time will quickly show how wobbly the back is on the ground withou training. And that's how wobbly your basing will be until you develop these core stability skills.
graduationRequirements: This is sutble: It's easy to rotate the leg. It's hard to get the squiggle movements out of the hip and torso.

lessons.title: Drill: Leg Tosses
lessons.synopsis: An excellent drill for bases
lessons.instructions:
1. The trainee lies on their back and raises both legs vertically to 90 degrees.
2. The supporting partner will toss the trainees legs to the left and right. The goal of the trainee is to resist as best as they can. And if they are overpower, it's to recover as best as they can after the throw.

Variations:---
- Have the trainee put the arms wide (= easy mode) and at the side of the body (= hard mode)
- Throw the legs in fast succession.
- Push and pull the legs. When pulling, the trainee should maintain a 90 degree angle at the hips and thus sit up. When pushing the legs, the back of the trainee should lift up in order to maintain the 90 degrees at the hip.


Intensity:---
Aim for a strong challenge, while keeping the trainee safe. Don't slam the trainee's fee into the ground. The ideal throw is so hard that the trainee can only recover the feet a moment before they would touch the ground.


Tip: Keep the shoulders on the ground:---
When having one's feet thrown, there is an intensity where one can generate enough leverage from the shoulders. That's when one can push against the throw with maxium strength.

However, there is a point where the throwing force is so great that it would roll the trainee onto the side. And once that happens, all leverage is lost. Thus, one has to learn to keep the shoulders flat on the ground for the greatest leverage. That will involve some strategic gift to stay right at the edge of rolling to the side. This is a great skill to drill.


Plus, the wider your shoulders connect to the ground, the more leverage you have. Picture a boat with around hull on the ground. It tips over instantly. Picture a grain with legs that come out at the side being much more stable.

You want to do the same with the shoulders. Don't round your back. Extend your shoulderblades against the ground as far as possible.
graduationRequirements: Can effectively resist side push with the arms wide..
Can effectifely resist with arms at the side.
Can recover from being overpowered by a push.
Can maintain 90 degrees at the hip when pushed.
Can maintain 90 degrees at the hip when pulled.

lessons.title: Concept Introduction: Postural Sway
lessons.synopsis: Explains postural sway to dispel myths that keep bases from finding balance.
lessons.instructions:
Goal:
A lot of novices have wrong ideas about human balance works, which keeps them falling over. This lesson introduces how postural sway works.

Instructions:
1. Introduce the concept of postural sway (see below).
2. Have the partner stand next to the wall. Have them align their shoulder with a spot on the wall and ask them to keep the shoulder still. The partner will discover that it's impossible to keep the shoulder still. And that's a great demonstration that postural sway is real because many people are unlikely to believe it without seeing it.
3. Explain how balance is achieved by constantly falling in the other direction to correct. And locking joints prevents the body from falling (= freezing degrees of freedom).
4. Use a light object to toss between you two to distract the partner from thinking about balance and encouraging movement. This should allow the natural postural sway to take over and improve balance.

Concept: Postural Sway:---
Many people believe that balance is achieved by putting the body into a perfectly balanced position and holdin that. This freezing of the body is actually counter productive because the body balances with postural sway.

In physical terms, a human body is very tall and has a very tight base, kind of like a stick. Things shaped that way like to fall over. 

The human solution is to constantly fall the other way. Say if the body is falling left, we initiated a movement to fall right. (We are so familiar with that movement that our mind blanks it out. And when we stand with both feet, we have decades of experience, which makes the movements small.)

The more we freeze joints and think about it, the more our cognitive mind inhibits the natural postural sway. So the exercise of tossing a light object to each other, does both: (1) It distracts the mind from interfering with the balance. (2) The random catching introduces movement that unlocks frozen joints.

Concept: Degrees of Freedom:---

Note:---
When I didn't use this, I saw surprisingly many novice bases who fell over like a dead stick. Not only did the not seem to be able to balance at all, but they also appeared to not even try but fall over like a dead stick. This exercise has mostly fixed that from happening.

lessons.title: Drill: Forearm Stand on Feet
lessons.synopsis: A great drill for bases to learn to avoid falling over
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back and has the legs straight up into the air. (There is a 90 degree bent at the hip.)
2. The flyer crosses their arms in front of the chest. (Try to crunch a bit to get the arms lower.)
3. The flyer places the arms and belly on the bases feet to be in the air.

Tip: Surprisingly man bases are confused about what they need to do to avoid falling over. If the flyer falls left, push them right, (and vice versa).


Variations:---
- If the static version is easy, the flyer can move the legs - gently at first, then running in the air, and finally wildly flailing.
- The flyer can also use the base's legs as canes and balance on them with stright arms down.
graduationRequirements: Can hold the flyer for 30 seconds.
Can hold the flyer while the flyer waves with their legs.

lessons.title: Pose: Hammock
lessons.synopsis: A super fun and easy pose that transforms all future park visits
lessons.instructions:
1. The base lies on their back with the knees bent and straight up.
2. The flyer sits down on the base's knees with their back facing the base's face.
3. The base will externally rotate the feet. The flyer will drape their "knee pits" over the base's feet.*
4. The flyer leans back onto the outstretcheed hands of the base**. The base should aim for the shoulderblades of the flyer.
5. The base straightens their legs. The flyer's hips should lift into the air.***
6. When ready to come down, the base bends the knees. The flyer sits back up on the base's knees.

Notes:
* Sometimes, there are physical differences that make this hard. E.g. the flyer has very short legs and the base has very long legs. Then the right position is easier to achieve once the flyer has reclined back. However, most of the time, the flyer simply has a conceptual block to understand what they are supposed to do.

** The base should walk their hands up the back of the flyer as the flyer leans back. This reassures the flyer that they are not leaning back into nothing.

*** Tips for form:
- Some flyers have to be encouraged to relax their hips and keep the knees bent.
- Bases should maintain a good bone stack with the hands (= straight elbows and arms stright up).


Spotting:---
As a spotter, you want to put your hands under the upper back of the flyer from the head side. The key goal is to protect the head and neck. If they legs fall, it's usually pretty uneventful because there is a tangle of base's legs in the way.


Alternative way to come down:---
An alternative way to come down is for the base to lower the hands. The flyer will still hang from their feet. This can be very nice for people who feel intimately comfortable with each other or in case of calamity.
graduationRequirements: The base's legs are bone stacked.
The base's hands are properly position under the flyer's shoulderblades.
The flyer's hips are relaxed.
The base can paddle the feet up/down.

lessons.title: Drill: Bird Receiving
lessons.synopsis: A preparatory drill for bird
lessons.instructions:
IMPORTANT! READ!
A lot of novices won't to skip through this drill and go directly to bird. It is so temptingly close. However, they usually set themselves up for getting stuck later.

The reason is that they get to bird by muscling it. Later they hit a hard wall when muscle can't get them further. And trying to do something harder makes it difficult to learn the technique.

Be patient and perfect this exercise. It'll make you leap ahead.

1. The base lies on their back with the arms along the side.
2. Flyer steps with their toes right up tot he base's finger tips. (This is a rule of thumb to get the right distance.)
3. The flyer places the base's feet on their hips so that middle of the balls of the feet of the base are on flyer's hip bone.
4. The flyer leans slightly forward and then turnts their body into a rigid plank.
5. The base bends the knees so that the flyer leans forward.
6. Stop after an inch or two and push the flyer back to standing.
7. Repeat this and go deeper each time.

Things to focus on:---
- Flyers need to keep their body rigid like a plank. It can take a lot of psychological learning to let go of control.

- Bases need to learn control:
-- Receive the flyer slowly. Don't let them fall into a freefall that freaks them out.
-- Be able to stop with precision.
-- Dose how far to push the flyer back so that they don't fall back.

- Learn to recognize the "hook point." That's when the flyers weight is completely on the base. (This will be key later and in many other poses to know that the flyer is ready to be pushed up.)


Spotting:---
The spotter stands at the side of the flyer:
- The spotter should stand in "goddess stance." That's the legs wide and bent. This allows them to lower the arms without bending and thus keep a good ergonimic body position to support the entire weight of the flyer if needed.
- The spotters arms are one under the tighs and one under the belly like a forklift. (Note, that's under the belly, not the boobs!)
- In case of a fall, the spotter can often simply help by getting the flyer centered again. If the fall is greater, the goal is to bring the flyer back towards their feet to protect the head and neck.
graduationRequirements: The base's feet are placed correctly (on the hip bone and parallel).
The flyer holds the shape. (No bend at the hips or premature reaching with the hands).
The base can control the receiving (no sudden plunge).
The base returns the flyer back to their feet without pushing the flyer over.

lessons.title: Bird
lessons.synopsis: The most quintessential pose to learn.
lessons.instructions:
1. Base lies on their back, legs up ninety degrees, and arms in the side.
2. The flyer steps up to the base from below until the flyers toes touch the bases finger tips. 
3. The base places their feet on the flyer's hips so that the balls of the feet are on the hip bone. 
4. The base bends the knees to receive the flyers weight. 
5. The hands wait until they connect naturally. 
6. Once the flyers weight is on the base, the base lifts the flyer and scoops them up with their heels.


Spotting:---
The spotters arms are underneath the flyer's belly and thighs respectively like a forklift.
graduationRequirements: Arms and legs are stacked.
Can hold bird for 30 seconds.
Can swivel side-to-side at least 45 degrees.
Can remove a foot.
Can leg press.
Can remove both hands.

lessons.title: Spotting: Bird fall drill
lessons.synopsis: A hands-on spotting exercise
lessons.instructions:
Goal: A lot of novices are too timid to assume a proper spotting position because it means being close to another person. Yet the result is that they won't be able to spot when needed. And that can get people hurt. This is a hands-on exercise to help people realize what they need to do to spot.

1. A base and flyer pair get into bird position.
2. The spotter assumes their position by having their arms under the flyer like a forklife. One arm is under the flyer's thighs. The other arm is under the flyer's belly.
3. The spotter should make sure that they are close enough, have knees bent, and the spine upright.
4. Then the base/flyer simulate a fall. The spotter should actually take the whole weight of the flyer so that they feel how much effort they have to put into holding the flyer.

courses.title: Argentine Tango
courses.description: Argentine Tango combines classical elegance and a deeply meditative connection between the partners.\n\nSessions available in LA: https://oxygentango.com

courses.title: Best Practices for Working From Home
courses.description: An introduction to applied attention science to help self-employed and remote employees who work from home make the most of their time and optimize their environment

lessons.title: Attention and how it works
lessons.synopsis: Attention and how it works
lessons.instructions:
Explore: How is attention different from time?

Metaphors for attention as a limited resource - come up with a few. 

Distinction: Directed vs involuntary attention. Brainstorm examples of each.  

Definition: Directed attention fatigue and its symptoms. Exchange stories. 

Distinction: Soft fascination vs hard fascination. Brainstorm examples of each. 

Explore: Audit of current practice of “attention breaks,” how restorative they are. 

Shape a small experiment that will increase the restorativeness of the breaks you take.
graduationRequirements: Did they come up with a novel metaphor that accurately presents attention as a limited resource?
Did they explain the difference between soft fascination and hard fascination with novel examples from their life?
Did they explain the difference between directed and involuntary attention with novel examples from their life?
Did they make a list of the kinds of breaks they normally take and accurately classify them in terms of the types of attention and fascination they exhibit?
Were they able to give an example from their life about how directed attention works, what the symptoms are when it is fatigued, and what is needed to restore it?
Did they frame a specific experiment that will make their breaks more restorative through increasing soft fascination?

lessons.title: Beginnings that support attention
lessons.synopsis: Beginnings that support attention
lessons.instructions:
Thinking of your typical week, what are all the moments that feel like beginnings? 

Tell a story of a beginning (day, week, meeting, session, project...) that felt wholesome and helped you focus. 

Explore/brainstorm: What are the ingredients or qualities of a “good beginning”? Identify dimensions like light, time of day, timers, words, space, rituals, props... 

Go further and audit all the possible important micro beginnings you experience each day/week that you may have overlooked. 

Choose an important one and design how you will use it to align purpose and direction of attention. 

Thinking about the workweek as a whole, shape a small experiment that will allow you to benefit from the energy of beginnings.
graduationRequirements: Did they make a full list of all the moments in their week that feel like beginnings or micro-beginnings?
Did they tell a story of a beginning and explain why it supported their attention using vocabulary from lesson 1?
Did they identify what specific elements help create good beginnings for them?
Did they frame a concrete, doable experiment for their worklife that will help them create beginnings that support directed attention?

lessons.title: Work sessions worth something
lessons.synopsis: Work sessions worth something
lessons.instructions:
Explore: What is work? How do you know when you are doing work? 

Brainstorm: What are all the different kinds of things you do that are work? 

Distinction: unitasking vs multitasking. Brainstorm examples of each. 

Distinction: reflection vs rumination. Brainstorm examples of each. 

Tell the story of a work session or work project that felt productive and enjoyable. 

Definition: Flow state 

Identify: which of the flow state ingredients tends to be missing for you? Complete immersion in a task, a balanced challenge-skill level, clear goals, immediate feedback, a sense of control, minimal distractions, a loss of self-consciousness, altered perception of time, and intrinsic motivation.  

Thinking about the important work you do, shape a small experiment that will allow you to enter a flow state.
graduationRequirements: Did they make a full list of all the kinds of work they do?
Did they come up with novel examples from their life of unitasking and multitasking?
Did they come up with novel examples from their life of reflection and rumination?
Did they share a specific story/example of being in a flow state when work was productive and enjoyable?
Did they frame a concrete, doable experiment for their worklife that will help remove obstacles and enter into a flow state ?

lessons.title: Closures that remove brain drain
lessons.synopsis: Closures that remove brain drain
lessons.instructions:
Explore: What does it mean to get “complete” on a task or worksession? 

Brainstorm: What are all the different kinds of completion/incompletion you experience in your work/life

Explore/brainstorm: What are the ingredients or qualities of a “good completion”? Identify dimensions like words, gestures, sounds, songs, habits, tracking...

Identify how incompletion feels. What “incompletes” tend to distract, worry, or bother you the most? 

Mindsweep: Set a timer for 8 minutes and write down all the incompletes that are on your mind. Include everything, long term, short term, work, personal life

Choose a moment that tends to leave you feeling incomplete (e.g., end of a worksession, conversation, meeting, workday, week, project) and design an experiment to create a feeling of completion while tracking next-step tasks.
graduationRequirements: Did they share what completion and incompletion looks like with real examples from their own life?
Did they identify what are the specific ingredients of that help them feel complete with something?
Did they identify the most distracting incompletions they have?
Did they complete the mindsweep exercise using incompletes from all parts of their life?
Did they frame a concrete, doable experiment to reduce the distraction of an incomplete?

courses.title: Bioregional Learning Center
courses.description: This course will support people who want to create a network for learning about their bioregion.

courses.title: Coding Interview Prep
courses.description: Prepare for DSA (Data Structures & Algorithm) coding interviews. Begin by reviewing fundamental data structures and algorithms. Then, hone your skills on commonly asked coding interview questions. This course is programming language agnostic.

lessons.title: Intro & Hello World
lessons.synopsis: Introduction to the Learning Labs and Hello World!
lessons.instructions:
(1) Start every mini-lesson with a short intro of each other.

(2) Provide an intro to the learning lab:
- Learn than teach
- Graduate only when you are ready
- The "Together Page" let's two people compare what they can teach each other. (How: Look up the other profile on the profile page and press the "together" button.)

(3) The learner shares their screen with their IDE and does a Hello World to ensure that everything is set up for shared coding in future mini-lessons.

(4) Answer any questions

Common Questions:---
Q: How do you prevent mentors from teaching wrong things?

A: First, before mentoring, another mentor has to graduate them for the particular lesson. Second, lessons are usually exercises or projects. So if the goal is to sort a string and the string doesn't sort right, you both know that the mentor didn't teach right.

Q: Why would anyone teach for free?

A: That's a common question that people have upfront. However, students who have tried it quickly embrace the teaching part because they are realizing that they are learning a lot from it. The learning part primes the information. However, the teaching (having to explain it and answer questions) really makes one get material.
graduationRequirements: Successfully shared the screen and ran Hello World

lessons.title: Big O Notation and Complexity Analysis
lessons.synopsis: Learn to classify algorithm efficiency using Big O notation and evaluate time/space trade-offs.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Introduce asymptotic performance.

(2) Review common Big O's and examples: O(k), O(log n), O(n),...

(3) Ask the student about the speed and space performance of common algorithms: Single loop, double loop, inserting into a linked list, binary search, different sort algorithms.

(4) Give the student a trick question where the code looks one way, but it calls a library method that changes the performance. (E.g. the code looks constant but the library method is linear.)
graduationRequirements: The student should confidently get the Big O notation correctly for at least three examples.

lessons.title: Problem-Solving Techniques (UMPIRE Method)
lessons.synopsis: Master a step-by-step approach to breaking down problems before coding, boosting clarity and confidence.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Introduce that interviewers look for how a coding problem is solved.

- Start by asking clarifying questions.
- Consider edge cases.
- Handle bad input.
- Match the problem to an algorithm.
- Discuss alternatives/improvements with the interviewer.
- After coding review the code and step through with sample values.
- ...

(2) Apply the concept by having the learner implement atoi (convert a string to an integer). Focus on how the learner handles the question, not the actual coding.

Note: Use itoa or similar for learners that repeat the lesson.
graduationRequirements: Thorough in discussing the problem before and after.

lessons.title: Implement An ArrayList
lessons.synopsis: Understand how an ArrayList works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have an ArrayList - a list structure that's backed by an array.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- add
- get
- remove

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

Note: Actual library implementations ahve various optimizations like bucketing. You may discuss that if there is time.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Linked List
lessons.synopsis: Understand how linked list works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a linked list - a list structure that provides constant time insertion.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- add
- get
- remove

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

Note: If there is time, discuss variations like a double-linked list.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Hash Table/Map
lessons.synopsis: Understand how an hash table/map works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a hash table or map - a structure that provides constant time lookup.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- add/put
- get
- remove

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

(3) As there is time, discuss topics like key collision.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Stack
lessons.synopsis: Understand how a stack works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a stack.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- push
- pop
- size

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.

Note: The learner can use a library method like an ArrayList, but not a Stack itself.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement A Queue
lessons.synopsis: Understand how a queue works by making one.
lessons.instructions:
Most languages have a queue.

(1) Ask the learner to implement one:
- constructor
- push
- pop
- size

(2) Ask the learner about the performance of each operation. This will be fundamental for future algorithm work.
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the functions within the given time.
The learner correctly discusses time and space complexity.

lessons.title: Implement Binary Search
lessons.synopsis: Binary Search is a common solution that has to be adapted for special cases.
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to implement binary search.

(2) Ask them to identify and step through to different cases.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_search
graduationRequirements: The learner can correctly implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Sorting 101: Quick Sort
lessons.synopsis: Implement quick sort to understand the basics of sorting
lessons.instructions:
(1) Ask the learner to implement quick sort. (Repeatedly sorting around a pivot point.)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quicksort
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Sorting 102: Merge Sort
lessons.synopsis: A basic algorithm that can be applied to in many different contexts
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to implement merge sort.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merge_sort
graduationRequirements: The learner can implement the algorithm within the given time.

lessons.title: Sorting 103: Insertion Sort
lessons.synopsis: Implementing insertion sort teaches a technique that's useful in specific cases.
lessons.instructions:
Ask the learner to implement insertion sort.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insertion_sort

courses.title: Experiencing and weaving communities of care
courses.description:
What if care wasn’t something we offered as an afterthought, but the very foundation of how we build, sustain, and transform communities?

This course is an experiential journey into what it truly means to create a Community of Care (COC)—not as an abstract idea, but as a lived practice. Together, we will explore:

🔹 How mutual care can transform relationships, organizations, and ecosystems
🔹 Why most communities struggle with invisible gaps in care—and how to address them
🔹 Practices to cultivate deep attunement, reciprocity, and shared holding
🔹 The first steps to co-weaving a Community of Care in your own life

This is not a theoretical course. It is a space of real-time connection, reflection, and practice. By the end, you won’t just understand what a COC is—you will have experienced it.

Are you ready to step into a different way of relating? Let’s begin.

lessons.title: Brainstorm A Project
lessons.synopsis: Create your own context for examples
lessons.instructions:
Pick a project that you are going to use to learn Flutter. Don't think to specific about something you want to build but rather pick an area, like a shopping list app or a party planning assistant.

Then create a document that covers the following:
(1) Overview of what your app is, e.g. an app to track events that you want to go ot.
(2) Things you want your app to be able to do, e.g. save an event, visualize them on a calendar.
(3) Catalog micro things that are in your app's domain. These will be useful for learning different programming aspects. E.g., sort events by date, sum the total cost of all events.
(4) Ideas for what would make your app really cool, e.g. monitor when tickets go on sale.

Use markdown syntax for the file. You want to become familiar with it if you haven't already.

https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax/

lessons.title: Install Flutter And IDE
lessons.synopsis: Gets you setup
lessons.instructions:
(Actual steps change over time. There are likely issues to do tooling bugs or your machine setup. Be prepared to have to do troubleshooting.)

1. Install Android Studio: https://developer.android.com/studio
(Be sure to let it install the Android SDK.)

2. Install Flutter: https://docs.flutter.dev/install/manual
(Be sure to run "flutter doctor" on the command line until all installation issues are resolved.)

3. Install VS.Code: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/setup-overview

4. Install the Flutter VS.Code extensions: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Dart-Code.flutter

5. On Mac: Install xcode.
(Run "flutter doctor --ios" on command line until all issues are resolved.)


Notes:
- We are installing VS Code and Android Studio so that you can evaluate which IDE you prefer. Both are capable IDEs. VS Code is lighter and simpler. Android Studio is more full featured.

- Expect to have to run flutter doctor multiple times and to have to resolve all kinds of random issues.

lessons.title: Install Git And Setup Github
lessons.synopsis: Start version control early on
lessons.instructions:
The goal is to get you setup with Git and Github.

1. Install git: https://git-scm.com/install/windows
2. Create a free account on Github: https://github.com/
3. Install Github: https://github.com/apps/desktop
4. Use the command line to create a new repo and add it to Github: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/quickstart-for-repositories?tool=cli
5. Add your project brainstorm file to your repository.
6. Check on the github website if your brainstorm file shows up.

Note: Most people have learned the hard way that losing files because of a lack of version control is very painful. Start using version control from the beginning!

This time, we are using Android Studio to create a hello world program. Android Studio will create a more sophisticated starting point for an app with multiple files.

1. Go to Android Studio.
2. Create a new flutter project with the wizard. Enable web and Android as the platforms.
3. Run the app in a browser.
4. Create an Android emulator.

lessons.title: Setting Up The OpenAI Coding Agent Codex
lessons.synopsis: Connect Codex to your GitHub repository
lessons.instructions:
Codex is the OpenAI coding agent. You connect it to your GitHub repository. You give it a task to code. You walk away for a few minutes. You come back and it offers you the code. You may ask it to make changes. Or you may accept it as a Github pull request and accept it into your project.

There are two ways to use it. You can use it through the ChatGPT web UI (recommended for this course) or through the command line/IDE integration (benefits that come at a cost not needed for the course).

1. Go to https://chatgpt.com and follow the instructions to setup codex and connect it to your repository.

(This may require getting a pro chatgpt account and various extra setup steps to enable two-factor authentication and so on.)

2. Give it two tasks: Give it a simple task like changing the background color of your page and a big task like creating a page that takes an event URL, reads it, and then reports the name, price, and location of the event in the UI.

3. Accept the simple task. Use Android Studio to pull the latest. Hot reload your app.

4. Look at the result of the complex task. It's likely quite a lot of code. And it probably also has quite a few issues. This is simply for you to get an idea of how it works.

Note: Using AI to learn Flutter is both a temptation and a liability. Asking Codex to solve a problem for you can show you how it is done. It can also answer your questions to get you unstuck. However, it'll also tell you wrong things. And you cannot let it become a crutch.

Use it to learn. However, always make sure that you can do everything on your own by actually doing it on your own. And always probe deeper to understand what's behind the answers by looking at real sources.

lessons.title: Install Your Hello World On Your Phone
lessons.synopsis: Get excited to show your app to your friends on yoru phone
lessons.instructions:
This is about installing your Hello World app on your phone. It's the final step to realizing your powers of creating an app that's running on your phone.

You'll have to do an initial configuration step that is phone dependent (Android or iPhone). After that, Android Studio should detect any phone plugged in with a USB cable. And you can simply hit the run button.

For Android:
You have to enable developer mode on your phone:
- Go to Settings > About Phone.
- Tap the build number seven times.

The official documentation with more details is here. You have to scroll down to "Setup an Android device" and select "Physical device":
https://docs.flutter.dev/platform-integration/android/setup

For iPhone:
You have to enable developer mode on your phone and create a certificate. Creating the certificate will require creating an Apple developer account.

The latest instructions are here. You'll need to scroll down to find them.
https://docs.flutter.dev/platform-integration/ios/setup

lessons.title: Communication Skills: Yes and...
lessons.synopsis: Develop collaboration skills
lessons.instructions:
Big Picture: Course Design Principles

A lot of programming courses focus on simply teaching the features of the API. This course is holistically designed to create an effective developer. A big part of that is to develop good communication skills. (Soft skills are often the deciding factor between successful developers.) The other part is that many real world needs don't fit neatly into how the APIs were designed.

To develop the soft skills and ability to deal with messy real world problems, the course is taught in a mentor-mentee model and learning examples are based on your individual project.

This lesson is to learn (or further develop) a brainstorming technique and develop your project idea more.

You want to focus on both having fun with your partner. (That's important for productive teams and great cooperation.) And you want to focus on creating lots of ideas that you can later turn into learning examples as the course touches upon relevant topics.

The technique is "Yes and..." Basically, you want to agree with what your partner said and build on the idea. Example: If your partner suggests a blue ocean theme for the app, agree with  the idea and build on it. You could build on it by suggesting that the naming convention should reflect the ocean theme. Users should be referred to as mermaids.

The point is not that every idea is brilliant. However, by being enthusiastic about it, it'll lead to something else. And eventually, there will be gold. You would have never gotten to the gold by shutting down the wild ideating.

Aim for a one-to-two-page bulleted list of various ideas for your app.

lessons.title: Communication Skills: Constructive Critical Questions
lessons.synopsis: A counter balance to "yes and.." is to inject critical thinking
lessons.instructions:
"Yes and..." is create for brainstorming ideas. The counter weight is to ask constructive critical questions. The point is to uncover realism. It's a different direction to develop project.

As a mentor, now that you know a bit about the individual project, ask the following types of questions:

(1) Challenge claims:
People will often make grand claims ("This app is great for everybody.") and general statements ("This is the fastest app.") You want to challenge these claims: Everybody? How about babies, blind people, etc. Fastest? What measurement do you use? Who is the competition?

(2) Identify assumptions:
People will often have assumptions like everyone will love the app because of something that they like. Point out the assumption and challenge it. Example: Aren't there some people who don't care so much about the speed of the app but more about the aesthetics?

(3) Dig into details:
People will often gloss over hard problems with hand waving. Sometimes, it's almost comical how people hide major unresolved complexity in a step with a pretty name. Ask details on how something is going to work exactly. Example: So you have a magic matching algorithm. What parameters are you going to use for the matching? What are you going to do in these edge cases.


Staying constructive: The careful choice is to stay constructive. "This is a bad idea!" is rather negative and doesn't invite more discussion. By asking challenging question, you can help people think through the solution better.


The outcome of this lesson should be a further developed individual project document. You two should have probably uncovered more tricky aspects that will make for great learning examples later.

lessons.title: Dart Data Types And Data Classes
lessons.synopsis: Get exposed to data types
lessons.instructions:
Apps have lots of data. Each datum has to have a type. Numbers, strings, and lists are common types. You'll learn about data types by creating data classes for your app.

1. Create a new directory/package* called "data" in your Android Studio project.

2. Pick an entity from your individual project, e.g. user, event, tree.

3. Create a new dart fiel in that package. (The naming convention in dart is all lower case and underscores "_" as spaces. The file name has to end in ".dart".)

4. Write "class [your entity name] {}". (Class names are upper camel case. Example: super_soaker.dart -> class SuperSoaker.)

5. In between parenthesis, write the different data fields (called properties from now on). The format is "[data type] [name];" Example: "int heightInInches;"

Here are dart data types: https://dart.dev/language/built-in-types

6. When you are done, hit control+shit+L. this should automatically format your code. It'll show you how could should be formatted.

7. Check that your code still compiles by re-running the app.

The outcome should be 3-5 classes with at least 5 properties each.

* A directory and package are the same thing in the real world (more or less). When you refer to it as a directory, you refer to what it is in the file system. When you refer to it as a package, you refer to it as a unit of code in your app.

Course design note:
Rather than spoon feeding every answer, the course creates a progressive path to learn flutter/dart. And it'll point you at resources to figure out answers.

It's quite time consuming to learn and memorize all data types without a concrete use. It's faster learning to have something concretely to do and learn how to teach yourself new data types.

lessons.title: Import The Math Package
lessons.synopsis: Learn how to include other packages and the very useful math package.
lessons.instructions:
We'll build on the previous lesson of building simple mathematical functions. To create more interesting functions, we'll learn how to include the math package. You can import a package, which makes all the functions and classes inside of it available to you.

1. Go back to Dart Pad: https://dartpad.dev

2. Take a look at what functions the dart library offers: https://dart.dev/libraries/dart-math

3. This is a more complete look at all the features of the dart library: https://api.dart.dev/dart-math/

4. In Dart Pad, import the math library by adding this on top: "import 'dart:math';"

5. Add 3-5 methods based on your individual project that use the math library.

6. Copy-and-paste your new methods into Android Studio like in the last lesson.

lessons.title: Useful String methods
lessons.synopsis: Introduction to useful string methods
lessons.instructions:
We'll continue our theme of making interesting functions for your individual project.

Here are a few useful string methods:
- 'a' + 'b' // Adds two strings together.
- 'abc'.length // Returns the length of the string
- ' a '.trim() // Removes whitespace at the start and end.
- 'ab'.toUpperCase() // Returns the string as upper case.
- 'abc'.indexOf('b') //returns the position of b (zero-based).
- 'abc.'.startsWith('ab') // Returns true of the string starts with 'ab'.

See the dart documentation for more: https://api.dart.dev/dart-core/String-class.html


Instructions:
1. Create 5-7 methods with string operations in your individual project.

lessons.title: Method Parameters
lessons.synopsis: A deep dive into method parameters
lessons.instructions:
Method parameters offer flexibility. Dart has positional and named parameters as well as default values.

Positional Parameters:
So far, we've known positional parameters. That is when a method is called, the parameters have to be provided in the same order.

void placeOrder(String drink, String dish, String dessert) {...}

placeOrder('juice', 'pizza', 'cake');


Named parameters:
Named parameters use a label and can be provided in any order. They can even be ommitted.

void placeOrder({String drink, String dish, String dessert = 'cookie') {...}

placeOrder(drink: 'juice', dish: 'pizza');

Notice that dessert is set to 'cookie' by default. Because we didn't specify it, it will become cookie.

Usage:
If there is a small number of parameters that are always supplied positional parameters are more succinct.

If there is a large number of parameters, named parameters provides better documenting code.

If there are a lot of optional parameters, named parameters make the most sense.


Instructions:
1. Create about three examples in your individual project.


Note: "required" is an important to know keyword. It makes a parameter required. This will make more sense later when you learn about nullability.

lessons.title: Declarative Vs. Procedural Programming
lessons.synopsis: A big mindset thing that will pay big dividents down the road.
lessons.instructions:
You've probably noticed that the last lessons showed you how to model code. And they didn't allow you to do many things.

That was on purpose to start you with the right mindset. There are two contrasting mindsets:

- Procedural programming is an approach where you think of the steps that need to be done and break down the steps into more details. This is a common way of thinking when starting to program.

- Declarative programming is when you declare what exists and is possible in your problem space. For example, you declare that dogs can be petted. Humans can pet. Humans have properties like name, height, and so on. Eventually, all of this gets connected by the compiler into step-by-step action like the compiler

To make a quick comparison, procedural programming is like giving step-by-step directions. And declarative programming is like giving a map. You can see that if you were to give step-by-step directions for driving across the country with stops at every national park, it would get quickly messy. Well written declarative code, can be very clean, easy to read, and extend.

With your mentor, pick a process in your individual project and go through it twice. Pick a process that's like the famous example of instructing a robot how to make a PBJ sandwich. 

(1) Go through the steps. Have your mentor challenge you to think of sub steps and details. You will probably quickly see how this is getting a bit messy.

(2) Start the declarative way. Start defining what kind of nouns exist, what properties they have and what behaviors.

Note: You will often need to model abstract concepts as classes. For example, in our dog example, we might create a Bark class.

lessons.title: Conditional code
lessons.synopsis: Introducing if-else statements

lessons.title: Comparison And Logical Operators
lessons.synopsis: How to formulate conditional expressions
lessons.instructions:
In the last lesson, we introduced if-statements. If-statements require understanding how to formulate expressions.

The basic recipe is that you usually have conditions that are true or not true. And then you combine them with logical operators.

Comparison operators:
- Equal "==": name == 'Mickey Mouse' (true if name is Mickey Mouse)

- Unequal "!=": name != 'Mickey Mouse" (true for everyone but Mickey Mouse)

- Less than "<": height < 5

- ">", "=>", and "<=" work as expected.

Multiple conditions can be combined:
- And "&&": a && b (a and b have to be true)
- Or "||": a || b (a, b, or both have to be true)

Parenthesis can be used to set priority of the operations.

Example:
- (a || b) && c -> c must be true and either a or b can be true

a: true, b: false, c: true -> result: true

- a || (b && c) -> b and c must be true or a must be true

a: true, b: false, c: true -> result: false

1. Work with your mentor to create 5-7 examples in your project. (Use these in if-statements.)

2. Take a look at the operator documentation in Dart: https://dart.dev/language/operators

lessons.title: Enums
lessons.synopsis: A useful construct for types
lessons.instructions:
Enums are another key feature of Dart that's essential to using Flutter. Often we need to define types of something, like types of dogs or clouds. We don't want to create a full class for it. Enums is what fits the bill.

Example:

enum Formats {
  portrait,
  landscape,
  square,
}

And then we can use it like this:

Formats dadsPictureFrame = Formats.portrait

if (somePictureFrame == Formats. square) {...


Background: In older days, programmers used magic numbers to mean certain things, like 1 for child and 2 for adult. However, these numbers are kind of magic. By using declared typs like PersonType.child, bugs are avoided and the code is clearer.


Instructions:
(1) Create 3-5 examples with your individual project.

(2) Take a look at the dart documentation: https://dart.dev/language/enums

lessons.title: Jobs-To-Be-Done (JTBD)
lessons.synopsis: To start our journey of building user experiences, it's good to learn JBTD design principles first.
lessons.instructions:
Jobs-To-Be-Done is a product design approach. It requires being able to see the world in a different way. Developing a perspective is more challenging than learning a fact. So getting this may require some personal engagement with different articles, videos, or a book. It may also not make sense for a while.

It is very much worth it to expand that effort. JTBD comes from research into why innovation at companies succeeds and why not. As it turns out, expertise of the team or big budgets did not affect success. It's a JTBD approach that matters.

You'll find long articles and video with lofty words, which can be rather empty and confusing. At the core, JTBD is solution-centered whereas the default for most people is product-centered. A use case is a process/goal that you can accomplish in the app. A job (in the JTBD framework) is something that you want to accomplish in real life.

An example for a car would be:
- Product centric: You'd think about improving features of the car: More horse power, better fuel efficiency, more expensive leather upholstery.

- Solution centric: You'd think about what people want to do, e.g. a family summer trip to go camping. What would make the long drive with the kids in the back more comfortable? What would be neat when being in the forest for a few days? E.g. keeping the dirt out, charging devices, etc.

Take a look at your personal project. Create two lists. List use cases and jobs. This should clarify in your mind the difference between the two.

(Listing the jobs will also make your app really useful!)

lessons.title: Excalidraw
lessons.synopsis: A drawing tool for diagrams and UI mockups
lessons.instructions:
Excalidraw is a website that lets you draw diagrams and mockup screens. It's commonly used in coding interviews. So it's a good tool to learn.

https://excalidraw.com/

A mockup is a draft of a user interface, e.g. a page/screen. Designers often create different types of mockups. A sketch or draft is a quick mockup to visualize and discuss the approach. A high fidelity mockup is a pixel perfect rendering of the UI. It often includes measurements, e.g. how large an image should be in pixels or the gap between two images in pixels. These measurements are often given in red, which gives these mockups the nickname "redlines."

Draw mockups for three of the screens in your personal project.

lessons.title: Text widget
lessons.synopsis: Learn your first UI widget
lessons.instructions:
You'll use the Text widget a lot. It'll probably be the most used widget.

The goal of this lesson is to look at the documentation for it and to change the Text widget in your Hello World app to experiment with different options.

Try some or more of the following:
- Change the text size.
- Change the font.
- Make it line wrap.
- Make the extra text be cut off with an ellipsis.

Documentation: https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Text-class.html

lessons.title: Container
lessons.synopsis: A common way to decorate widgets
lessons.instructions:
A Container widget is a common solution to when we need something around a widget. Frequent uses are to add a background color or padding. However, you'll find all kinds of unusual problems where a Container offers a solution.

Example:
Container(
  color: Colors.blue,
  padding: const EdgeInsets.all(16),
  margin: const EdgeInsets.only(top: 8),
  child: Text('Hello'),
)

Play around with the options of a container by creating your own.

Documentation: https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Container-class.html

lessons.title: Columns and Rows
lessons.synopsis: The bread and butter for layouts
lessons.instructions:
A column allows you to put multiple widgets on top of each other. A row allows you to put multiple widgets side by side.

The real magic comes from nesting colums and rows inside of each other. When you look at real UIs, they won't appear like simple rows and columns.  However, by smartly nesting them in each other, you can implement the majority of layouts.

Commonly used properties are:
- crossAxisAlignment: Controls if the widgets are centered or aligned to one side.
- mainAxisAlignment: Allows the space to be distributed as: spaceBetween, spaceAround, and spaceEvenly

Take one of your screen mockups and implement it with columns and rows. Because you don't have other widgets that you need, you can simply put text as space holders there, e.g. "[button goes here]".

lessons.title: Expanded and Flexible
lessons.synopsis: Change the space that items in a Row or Column take up
lessons.instructions:
A key paradigm of Flutter is that everything is a widget. This lesson gives you an example of how you'll be putting lots of widgets inside of widgets.

In the last lesson, we learned about Rows and Columns. All the children were equally distributed. However, layouts often need all the extra space to go to one widget.

Imagine you have a row with a text widget that's a label and a text input field. You'd want the label text to only take up as much space as is needed. All the extra space should go to the input field. You achieve that by "wrapping" the text input field inside of an Expanded widget.

Example:
Row(children: [
  Text('Secret'),
  Expanded(child: Text('[input field goes here]')),
]);

Expanded is a special case of Flexible Flexible is the more generic widget that gives you more options.

You can also specify the ratio tha widgets should take up. Say that you have a profile image and name. You want the ratio between them to be 1:2.

Example:
Row(children: [
  Flexible(fit: 1, child: Text('[profile image here])),
  Flexible(fit: 2: child: Text('Jane Smith')),
]);

You can find the documentation here:
- Expanded: https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Expanded-class.html
- Flexible: https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/Flexible-class.html


Create your own examples to play with them.

lessons.title: AssetImage Widget
lessons.synopsis: Adding images
lessons.instructions:
Images are what catches the eyes of users. You are likely going to have images that are built into the app and user provided images. We'll add user provided images in this lesson. Uploading and storing images is a big subject for another time.

You'll have to do the following steps:
(1) Declare an asset folder

In your pubspec.yaml file, you'll have to declare where you'll add assets like images in your directory structure.

You'll typically add something like this:
flutter:
  assets:
    - directory/
    - directory/subdirectory/

(2) Add the actual image.
You have to add an actual image to that directory.

Unsplash is a great website for free stock photos. You can find a lot of useful photos here, which you can use for free. It makes apps and marketing material look great.

https://unsplash.com

(3) Add the image to your UI:
Here is how you'll add the widget to your widget tree:
Image(image: AssetImage('assets/background.png'))


Documentation: https://docs.flutter.dev/ui/assets/assets-and-images

Note: This often doesn't work out. The issue often has to do with the path to the asset. A missing or extra '/' can be the culprit. Or you don't have all the parts of the path or too many parts.

lessons.title: Intro To ListView
lessons.synopsis: ListView is a workhorse of layouts
lessons.instructions:
You'll find that a lot of app layouts are lists of things that the user scrolls through, e.g. Spotify song lists, Instagram newsfeed. A lot of design focus is spent on creating these lists and to make them fast and performant. The ListView widget is the workhorse for that.

Here is a simple static implementation of ListView. You simply provide it with a list of widgets.

ListView(
  children: [
    Container(height: 300, color: Colors.red, child: Text('Item 1')),
    Container(height: 300, color: Colors.blue, child: Text('Item 2')),
   //...
  ],
)

This was quick to get started. However, all the child widgets are going to be created. If we have 500 songs to scroll through, this will be very expensive.

Using a builder pattern, the ListView will create items only when they become visible on the screen. The builder pattern is a common pattern shared by many Flutter widgets.

In this example, we are providing a list of country names. And the builder creates a widget for each country as needed.

final countries = [
      'USA',
      'Canada',
      'Mexico',
      'Brazil',
      'Argentina',
      'UK',
      'France',
      'Germany',
      'Italy',
      'Spain',
      'China',
      'Japan',
      'South Korea',
      'India',
      'Australia',
    ];

    return ListView.builder(
      itemCount: countries.length,
      itemBuilder: (context, index) {
        return Container(
          height: 200,
          alignment: Alignment.center,
          color: index.isEven ? Colors.grey[300] : Colors.grey[200],
          child: Text(countries[index]),
        );
      },
    );

We'll go into handling data in an entire level later.

Now, build your own lists in your personal project.

Documentation:
https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/ListView-class.html

https://docs.flutter.dev/cookbook/lists/long-lists

courses.title: Home barista
courses.description: The Four-Week Home Barista Course is designed to take you from espresso novice to confident home barista. In just four weeks, you'll master essential espresso-making skills, including pulling the perfect shot, frothing milk, and creating beautiful latte art. Each week focuses on a new set of practical, hands-on lessons, guiding you through the tools, techniques, and flavors that professional baristas use every day. By the end of the course, you'll be able to craft café-quality drinks from the comfort of your kitchen. Perfect for coffee lovers looking to elevate their daily brew!

lessons.title: Espresso Machine Setup
lessons.synopsis: Learn the parts and functions of your espresso machine—master the basics so you can pull a proper shot.
lessons.instructions:
1. Show how to fill the water reservoir and turn on the machine.
2. Demonstrate grinding and loading the portafilter.
3. Walk the learner through tamping and locking the portafilter.
Pull an espresso shot together.
4. Let the learner practice the full process.

Notes---
Setting up the espresso machine properly is crucial to making great coffee. Pay attention to the grind size, tamping pressure, and water levels. These factors will affect the flavor of the espresso. Encourage the learner to experiment with the grind and tamp to see how it impacts the shot. It’s normal for new users to make a few mistakes while finding the right balance, so don’t rush the process!
graduationRequirements: Can set up machine independently.

lessons.title: Pulling the Perfect Shot
lessons.synopsis: Understand the key variables to pull a balanced espresso shot.
lessons.instructions:
1. Show how to grind the coffee and tamp evenly.
2. Set the ideal shot time (25-30 seconds).
3. Watch the espresso pour, noting color and texture.
4. Let the learner pull a shot and adjust as needed.
5. Taste and discuss the results.

Notes---
A balanced shot should have rich crema and smooth flavor. The learner will start adjusting grind size, tamp pressure, and shot time to perfect this.
graduationRequirements: Can pull a shot in 25-30 seconds with proper crema.

lessons.title: Espresso Tasting and Calibration
lessons.synopsis: Learn to taste espresso and identify under, balanced, and over-extraction.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull shots with varying settings (grind size, tamp).
2. Taste and compare each shot.
3. Discuss flavor notes for under and over-extracted shots.
4. Adjust settings for a balanced shot.
5. Taste and refine based on preference.

Note---
Developing taste sensitivity takes time. Focus on body, acidity, and bitterness. Small adjustments make a big difference.
graduationRequirements: Can identify under, balanced, and over-extracted espresso.

lessons.title: Cleaning and Maintenance
lessons.synopsis: Learn the importance of regular cleaning and maintenance to keep your machine in top condition.
lessons.instructions:
1. Clean the portafilter and steam wand after use.
2. Show how to backflush the machine.
3. Explain when and how to descale the machine.
4. Let the learner clean the machine themselves.
5. Discuss how regular cleaning extends the machine’s life.


Notes:---
A clean machine produces better-tasting espresso and lasts longer. Always clean after every use.

lessons.title: Milk Steaming Basics
lessons.synopsis: Learn how to properly steam milk for espresso drinks.
lessons.instructions:
1. Show how to fill the milk jug to the right level.
2. Position the steam wand just under the surface.
3. Steam until the milk expands and reaches 140-150°F.
4. Let the learner practice steaming milk.
5. Discuss how texture impacts the drink.


Notes---
Proper microfoam is key for lattes and cappuccinos. The milk should be silky, not frothy. Steaming too hot can scald it.
graduationRequirements: Can steam milk to 140-150°F with microfoam.

lessons.title: Pouring Basic Latte Art
lessons.synopsis: Begin creating simple latte art, starting with hearts.
lessons.instructions:
1. Steam milk until smooth and silky.
2. Pull an espresso shot and prepare the cup.
3. Demonstrate pouring to create a heart shape.
4. Let the learner try pouring.
5. Refine the pour technique based on feedback.


Notes---
The art is in the pour. Begin slow, practicing height and flow rate to perfect the heart shape.
graduationRequirements: Can pour a basic heart shape with proper texture.

lessons.title: Cappuccino vs. Latte Milk Texture
lessons.synopsis: Understand the difference in milk textures for cappuccinos and lattes.
lessons.instructions:
1. Steam milk for a cappuccino, creating more froth.
2. Steam milk for a latte, focusing on smooth microfoam.
3. Compare the textures side by side.
4. Let the learner prepare both milk types.
5. Taste and discuss the difference in texture and drink experience.


Notes---
Cappuccinos are more foam-forward, while lattes are creamier. Mastering both textures is essential for crafting different drinks.

lessons.title: Making a Flat White
lessons.synopsis: Learn to prepare a flat white, a milk drink known for its velvety texture.
lessons.instructions:
- Steam milk with a focus on minimal foam.
- Pull a double shot of espresso.
- Pour the milk carefully to preserve a silky texture.
- Let the learner try to create a flat white.
- Discuss the key differences between a flat white and a latte.


Notes---
The flat white has a stronger coffee flavor due to the double shot, with just enough milk to balance it. Precision in milk steaming is key.

lessons.title: Making a Cappuccino
lessons.synopsis: Perfect the classic cappuccino with its distinct foam-to-milk ratio.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a single or double shot of espresso.
2. Steam milk to create a thick foam.
3. Pour the milk, focusing on foam first.
4. Let the learner prepare their cappuccino.
5. Discuss how to achieve the right foam height.

Notes---
Cappuccinos should be light and airy, with a thick foam layer on top. Practice is needed to control the foam while pouring.
graduationRequirements: Can make a cappuccino with proper foam-to-milk ratio.

lessons.title: Iced Latte Basics
lessons.synopsis: Learn how to make a refreshing iced latte with cold milk and espresso.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a shot of espresso and let it cool.
2. Fill a glass with ice.
3. Pour cold milk into the glass.
4. Add the cooled espresso shot.
5. Let the learner prepare their own iced latte.

Notes---
Iced lattes are popular in warm weather. Ensure the espresso cools slightly before adding it to the ice to avoid dilution.

lessons.title: Americano Perfection
lessons.synopsis: Master the Americano, a diluted yet strong espresso-based drink.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a shot of espresso.
2. Boil water and fill a cup halfway.
3. Pour the espresso into the water.
4. Let the learner prepare their Americano.
5. Discuss the drink’s strength and versatility.


Notes---
The Americano offers a smoother, less intense flavor compared to straight espresso. It’s ideal for those who prefer a longer coffee drink.

lessons.title: Crafting a Cortado
lessons.synopsis: Learn to make a cortado, a balanced espresso and milk drink.
lessons.instructions:
1. Pull a double shot of espresso.
2. Steam a small amount of milk (equal ratio to espresso).
3. Pour the milk to create a smooth blend.
4. Let the learner make their own cortado.
5. Discuss the balance of coffee and milk in this drink.


Notes ---
A cortado is perfect for those who prefer less milk and more coffee flavor. The key is the 1:1 espresso-to-milk ratio.

lessons.title: Advanced Latte Art – Rosetta
lessons.synopsis: Learn to pour a rosetta, one of the most advanced latte art designs.
lessons.instructions:
1. Steam milk to create smooth microfoam.
2. Pull an espresso shot and prepare the cup.
3. Demonstrate pouring to create a rosetta pattern.
4. Let the learner practice the pour.
5. Refine technique and troubleshoot common issues.

Notes:---
Rosetta requires steady hands and control over milk flow. Precision is key, and it may take multiple attempts to perfect.
graduationRequirements: Can pour a recognizable rosetta.

lessons.title: Manual Brewing Techniques – French Press
lessons.synopsis: Learn the basics of manual brewing with a French press for a full-bodied coffee experience.
lessons.instructions:
1. Measure coarse coffee grounds (1:15 ratio with water).
2. Add hot water and stir to saturate.
3. Steep for 4 minutes, then press down the plunger.
4. Pour and taste the coffee.
5. Let the learner try the brewing process.


Notes---
French press offers a more robust coffee flavor. The longer steeping process allows more oils and flavors to extract from the grounds.

lessons.title: Espresso Machine Troubleshooting
lessons.synopsis: Learn to diagnose common espresso machine issues and perform basic troubleshooting.
lessons.instructions:
1. Identify common issues (grind too fine, shot pulling too fast).
2. Adjust grind size and tamp pressure.
3. Clean the portafilter and check water flow.
4. Let the learner troubleshoot an issue with guidance.
5. Test and review the results.

Notes---
Regular machine maintenance reduces the likelihood of problems. Knowing how to troubleshoot ensures consistent shot quality.
graduationRequirements: Can adjust grind size.
Can clean the machine.

lessons.title: Signature Drink Creation
lessons.synopsis: Create a signature espresso-based drink by experimenting with flavors and techniques.
