lessons.title: Orphan Fisherman Boss
lessons.synopsis: Get up and moving with your partner and your friends, the first three game pieces in parallel system.
lessons.instructions:
Start with Orphan, Fisherman, Boss. 

Make a sequence of three moves and do it twice in a row. 

For example: “Orphan Fisherman Boss” is the sequence of three moves. “Orphan Fisherman Boss Orphan Fisherman Boss” means you did it twice in a row. 

Now, put the same cards (Orphan, Fisherman, and Boss) in a different order. Do the new sequence, twice in a row. 

Repeat it til it flows and you can remember the names. 

[OLYMPICS] Record your sequence and share. 

NOTE: When you pick three cards and dance it twice in a row we call it a 3X2.

lessons.title: Three Orphans
lessons.synopsis: Get the hang of the three different kinds of Orphans so you can choose the right one for your context.
lessons.instructions:
Do Fisherman Orphan with an advancing Orphan. Then do it again, this time with a lateral Orphan. 

Do Boss Orphan with a retreating Orphan. Then do it again, this time with a lateral Orphan. 

Put the three cards (Orphan, Fisherman, Boss) in a new random order, one that’s different from the first challenge, and do a 3X2.   

Do the new sequence using an advancing Orphan, then with a lateral Orphan, then with a retreating Orphan. Decide which version you like best.

Repeat it til it flows and you can remember the names. 

[OLYMPICS] Record your sequence and share.

lessons.title: Fool and Bartender
lessons.synopsis: Practice and smooth out random combos of all five parallel system non-sacada game pieces.
lessons.instructions:
Do Orphan Fool. 

Do Orphan Bartender. 

Do Orphan Fool Bartender in a 3X2. 

Pick at least two of the following nice combos and dance it in a 3X2. For the sequences that have Orphan, decide whether you want it advancing, lateral, or retreating.  
- Boss Orphan Fool
- Fool Orphan Bartender
- Fisherman Bartender Fisherman

Take all five cards (Orphan Fisherman Boss Fool Bartender) and draw three randomly. Do the sequence in a 3X2. Repeat it til it flows and you can remember the names. 

[OLYMPICS] Record your sequence and share.

courses.title: Tango Learning Lab - Boise
courses.description:
Peer-to-peer curriculum for learning Argentine tango.

Organized by Tommy Smith

lessons.title: Connected Movement
lessons.synopsis: This exercise introduces the concept of lead/follow and how we move in a connected manner.
lessons.instructions:
One person makes movements, and the other copies them.

-Stand in front of each other without touching
-Movement options are weight changes and side/forward/back steps
-Switch roles
-Switch roles without speaking

Key concepts:
-Lead and follow: One person initiates the movement, the partner responds
-Frontality: Keeping your heart in front of your partner's heart
-Proximity: Maintaining the same distance to your partner throughout the movement
-Waiting: Moving slowly and not anticipating (follow)
-Intention: showing you are starting a movement before actually moving (lead)
graduationRequirements: Can lead the movements without leaving partner behind
Can follow movements while maintaining proximity
Can follow movements without getting ahead of the partner

courses.title: Tango Manual
courses.description: Mitra and Stefan's original peer-to-peer tango curriculum from Oxygen

lessons.title: Mirror Game
lessons.synopsis: This exercise practices and introduces deep connection in leading/following.
lessons.instructions:
One person makes movements. The other copies them.

1. Start with big, slow upper body movements.
2. Work to more subtle movements.
3. Switch lead.
4. Switch lead without speaking.

Tips: 
- Find a place where there isn’t dance traffic.
- Ask the host to play lyrical music
graduationRequirements: Did they mirror your movements? Could you easily mirror theirs?
Did they yield/receive the lead silently without interrupting flow?

lessons.title: Shadow Legs
lessons.synopsis: The upper body mirrors. The lower body shadows.
lessons.instructions:
1. Play Mirror Game using big slow leg movements
2. Work to smaller movements like side steps and weight changes
3. Switch lead
4. Show practice hold
5. Walk forwards, backwards, sideways
6. Show how lower body shadows while upper body mirrors
7. Switch lead

Tips: 
- Ask them to “send” their embrace towards you
- Exaggerate the tone in the embrace
- Identify the different parts of the step: extend, weight transfer, passing through
graduationRequirements: Did they accurately mirror your steps and weight changes?
Did they share weight changes, side steps, forward and back steps as leader and follower?
Did they invite before stepping when leading, extend before stepping?

lessons.title: Side-By-Side
lessons.synopsis: Synchronized walking side-by-side. Builds on natural instinctual ability to walk through a space, lead and follow, which people usually lose when they are put into a formal dance situation.
lessons.instructions:
1. Walk side by side, arms around backs
2. Play with double time, half time and pauses
3. Switch the lead

Tips
- You don’t need to start on the same leg
- The idea is to take the same size steps at the same time
- Pausing (staying on one foot) vs weight shifts (marching in place)

Bonus!
- Play with a few really long pauses
- Tell them about the line of dance
graduationRequirements: Did they stand upright and match your step size and timing?
When they were leading was it easy for you to follow them?
Were they able to match the faster and slower steps?

lessons.title: First Figure
lessons.synopsis: Boxy six count step that travels down line of dance. This exercise shows the rich possibilities of improvising with a basic pattern.
lessons.instructions:
1. Lead the step. It is a rectangular pattern that begins with a side step with leader’s left and follower’s right.
2. Add rock steps
3. Rotate it counterclockwise
4. Add pauses
5. Alter step size
6. Switch roles and do 1-5.

Tips: 
- Introduce syncing up
- Highlight inline vs. outside partner
- Explain FRONTALITY
- Backlead when you first switch roles
graduationRequirements: Did they lead and follow the structure several times, connecting each part into a flowing motion?
Were they able to lead and follow each of the variations (pauses, rocking, rotation, step size)?
Can they explain the definitions of inline, outside partner, and frontality?

lessons.title: The Cross
lessons.synopsis: The 8-count salida with the follower’s cross.
lessons.instructions:
Steps: 
1. Demonstrate the Cross solo
2. Have them copy you
3. Lead them to the cross and resolution
4. Alternate between the Cross and the First Figure.
5. Have them lead it
6. Have them alternate between the two figures.

Tips
- Be sure they really transfer weight when they cross: explain free leg/standing leg
- Both partners hips should face each other at the cross
- Have the leader study the follower’s crossed legs, to see which leg to step with after the cross.

Bonus!
Explain the cross is a default for the follower. The follower does it unless the leader interrupts.
graduationRequirements: Did they maintain Alignment and Frontality through all parts of the step, including the cross, in each role?
Are the weight changes of the cross correct both when they lead and when they follow?
Can they explain the difference between the free leg and the standing leg?

lessons.title: Forward Ocho
lessons.synopsis: How to do the forward ocho.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Demonstrate the Forward Ocho at the wall
2. Have them copy you
3. Explain the parts of the ocho: Extend, Step, Pivot, Extend
4. Repeat Forward Ochos in practice hold
5. Execute Forward Ochos from the Cross.
6. Learn exiting Forward Ochos to a side step

Drill: Imagine the leader has two belly buttons, one left, one right. To invite the forward ocho on the left side, the left belly button pulls back, and vice versa on right side. 

Tips
- Be sure they PIVOT FULLY before reaching to the next step
- Highlight: The follower’s part takes longer than the leader’s part
- Highlight: The far side of the follower becomes the near side
- When they lead, let them problem-solve how to exit the ocho.
graduationRequirements: Did they extend, then transfer, then pivot fully before stepping?
Did they invite the ocho, support it, and give their partner enough time to do it?
Can they explain the difference between the far side and the near side?

lessons.title: Backward Ocho
lessons.synopsis: How to do the backward ocho
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Demonstrate the Backward Ocho at the wall
2. Have them copy you
3. Review the parts of the ocho: Extend, Step, Pivot, Extend
4. Repeat Backward Ochos in practice hold
5. Learn exiting Backward Ochos

Tips
- Have them stay super close to wall so they’re not falling
- Make sure they EXTEND backwards fully, before stepping
- Reinforce LEADER'S INVITATION
- Remind leader to focus on the follower’s body through whole pivot
- Highlight: The follower’s part takes longer than the leader’s part
- Highlight: The near side of the follower becomes the far side

Bonus!
- “Which Ocho?” Game: Side step, then have FOLLOWER choose
- “Which Ocho?” Game: Side step, then have LEADER invite
graduationRequirements: Did they extend, then transfer, then pivot fully before stepping?
Did they invite the ocho, support it, and give their partner enough time to do it?

lessons.title: Parada Play
lessons.synopsis: The mechanics of Parada-Sandwich-Pasada. The movement has the effect of changing a Backward Ocho into a Forward Ocho.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead Backwards Ochos
2. Lead the Parada to the hugward side.
3. Talk them through the parts:
- Leader stops the ocho (Parada)
- Leader Sandwiches
- Leader Steps back
- Follower Sandwiches
- Follower steps over (Pasada)
- Forward Ochos and exit

Tips
- Explain that if feet touch we stop.
- Lower your body to stop the follower mid-ocho.
- Follower chooses the timing for when to step over.
- For both to be comfortable and Aligned, the embrace needs to be very flexible. 
- Explore when and where to adjust the arms.

Bonus!
- Explain adornments!
graduationRequirements: Do they adapt the embrace so both people stay aligned?
Do they create a pause at the parada and an unrushed exit?

lessons.title: Tango Sentence
lessons.synopsis: How to travel down the line of dance using tango elements. This exercise brings together the previous elements. The idea is to find a feeling of flow as you do it.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Explain the structure of the sentence: Side step -> Backward Ochos -> The Cross -> Forward Ochos -> Side step
2. Zoom in on transition from Backwards Ochos to the Cross, doing it slowly several times.
3. Execute it several times with different numbers of Ochos.

Tips
- Stay in outside lane and travel downstream
- Leader faces outward toward walls/mirrors/tables
- Handward side of embrace points down line of dance
- It doesn’t matter which system the leader uses to get to the Cross.
- Point out how little the leader moves vs the follower.
- Leader should keep their body frontal to partner. To do this they need to switch feet on ocho exits.

Bonus!
- “How Many Ochos?” Game: Let them decide in advance how many ochos they’ll follow: ODD number of backwards ochos, EVEN number of forward ochos.
- Backleading this, while telling them verbally what to do with their feet, really helps a first-time leader
graduationRequirements: Are they able to do the tango sentence down the line of dance?
Can they explain floorcraft?
When leading do they do the right number of extra weight changes to make it work?
Can they do it with different numbers of ochos?

lessons.title: The Other System
lessons.synopsis: The difference between parallel (“normal”) system and the other system.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Explain Tango Figures are defined by what the FOLLOWER does. (The SAME figure can be done in many different ways, by the leader doing different footwork)
2. Review the Cross with them leading
3. Have them problem-solve and find a different way to do the same Figure
4. Teach the Secret Weight Shift.
5. Learn to do the Cross after a secret weight shift.

Tips
- During secret weight shift, the embrace should stay very still.
- Direct follower’s focus on what they feel, not what they see
- Leader’s footwork to the Cross is after secret shift is Left, Right.

Bonus!
- Explain parallel system vs crossed system nomenclature
- Quiz: How do we get from one system to the other? Answer: One person switches feet without the other.
- Explore: Which system are we in when we do Ochos? How did we get into it, how do we get out of it?
graduationRequirements: Can they explain the difference between parallel and crossed system?
Can they explain how we change from one system to the other?
Can they do a secret weight shift when leading?
When following do they follow instead of guessing what to do?

lessons.title: Soft Boleo
lessons.synopsis: New dramatic gateway between ochos.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Define boleo: turning a BACKWARDS pivot into a FORWARDS one (or vv)
2. Lead backward ochos
3. Lead change of pivot from backwards to forwards
4. Lead forward ochos
5. Switch roles

Tips
- Follower’s full back Extension makes boleo possible
- Follower keeps foot on the ground throughout extension and Pivot
- When they lead, timing’s key: boleo pivot is led at END of extension but BEFORE weight transfer

Bonus!
Try a forward boleo!
graduationRequirements: Do they invite the change of direction of the pivot clearly and at the right time?
When following do they extend fully with foot on ground?
When leading do they allow enough time and support for the whole pivoting action?

lessons.title: Turning Ochos
lessons.synopsis: Sculpting ochos into nooks and crannies.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead repeated forward ochos while turning clockwise (e.g., 2-3 ochos north, east, south, west)
2. Do it counterclockwise
3. Lead repeated backward ochos while turning clockwise
4. Do it counterclockwise
Switch roles and repeat

Tips
- Point out how different each pivot is
- Leader should give follower enough time for each pivot
- Leader should make space for the far side of the follower’s body

Bonus!
Dance in the context of a Tango Sentence
graduationRequirements: Can they repeat turning ochos in a full 360 degree circle?
Can they do these both clockwise and counterclockwise?
Can they do these with both forward and backward ochos?

lessons.title: The Box
lessons.synopsis: Easy pattern with lots of variants to quickstart milonga.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead the box step, a six-count square pattern that starts w/leader retreating inline with right leg.
2. Occasionally add 1 or 2 extra steps hugward at the end (top) of the box. This ensures weight shifts are being accurately communicated.
3. Make the box step rotate clockwise
4. Switch roles.

Tips
- When they lead, be sure you can feel them leading the weight shifts
- Point out that the whole box step is in parallel system

Bonus!
Define basic terms: tanda, tango, milonga (the party), milonga (the music)
graduationRequirements: When leading, is it easy for partner to perceive invited weight changes?
When following, do they make their weight changes clear and obvious (FOLLOWER's POWER)?
Can they correctly define terms tanda, tango, and the two senses of milonga?
Were they able connect the Box and variants several times in a flow in each role?

lessons.title: The Comb
lessons.synopsis: Varation on easy box that travels down line of dance.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead the first four steps of the box (three sides of the box, minus the top)
2. Repeat, and travel down the line of dance
3. Occasionally, add the box-top anytime, to make sure communication is happening

Tips
- The couple’s handward side should be pointed down line of dance, so the Comb travels continuously downstream

Bonus!
- Following the follower! The FOLLOWER decides when we switch from Box to Comb and the leader adapts to her choice.
graduationRequirements: When leading: can you reliably convey the difference between The Box and The Comb?
When leading: can you reliably perceive the difference between The Box and The Comb?
When leading, do you adapt to the follower's misperceptions?
When following, do you show the leader clearly what side you are on even if unsure?

lessons.title: Forward-Forward
lessons.synopsis: Big juicy relaxing steps for contrast.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead the first step of the Box, which is the first “forward” for the follower
2. Lead the follower forward again, this time outside-partner
3. Lead a side step hugward, turning a quarter turn
4. Lead a weight change
5. Repeat

Tips
- Point out that walking forward is nice contrast for followers, since they mostly walk backwards
- Remind them to land heels-first when walking forward
- Lead first two steps BIG and keep LOW; last two steps UP and SMALL
- To make room for follower’s second forward step outside-partner, leader’s first step should be like on a tightrope

Bonus!
When they lead, have them figure out how to start to it navigates (Answer: Start backwards!)
graduationRequirements: When following do they take large steps forward landing heel first?
When leading, can your follower clearly distinguish between Forward Forward and The Box?
Can you mix this with The Box and The Comb down the line of dance?

lessons.title: The Line
lessons.synopsis: Calmly going back and forth together in a slot.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead advancing outside-partner step (third step in Box)
2. Lead weight change
3. Lead retreating step inline
4. Lead weight change

Tips
- Basically shrinking both side steps of box, making them weight shifts
- When they lead, make sure they’re leading & reading the weight shifts

Bonus!
Make it rotate counterclockwise (change facing on weight shifts)
graduationRequirements: Can they explain the difference between The Line and The Box?
When leading, can they integrate The Line into a flow with the other elements?
When following are they able to perceive clearly-invited weight changes, and make clear choices when the invitation is ambiguous?
In both roles, do they maintain tone in the embrace?

lessons.title: The Stair
lessons.synopsis: Zigzagging down line of dance together.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead advancing outside-partner step (third step in Box)
2. Lead weight change
3. Lead side step (top of the Box)
4. Lead weight change
5. Repeat

Tips
- Slow down and focus on each weight change, make sure these are being fully communicated
- When stepping side, the leader should land with weight a little forward

Bonus!
- Simon Says Game 1! Follower calls out “Box” or “Stair” and leader needs to switch to the new patter with the very next step.
- Simon Says Game 2! Pick threee missions in the Milonga ring. Follower calls out which one to do and the leader leads it next.
graduationRequirements: When leading, can they make invitations that clearly convey whether it is a Box, a Stair, a Line or a Comb?
When leading, do they travel down the line of dance?
When following, can they accurately discern what direction the leader is inviting?
Are all weight changes fully shared and with the music?

lessons.title: The Traspie
lessons.synopsis: Double time rhythm that adds energy and alertness.
lessons.instructions:
Steps
1. Lead “testing the waters”: sending weight halfway into a side step then returning
2. Lead a weight change in place
3. Lead a retreating inline step
4. Repeat, and this time do an advancing outside-partner step after the weight change

Tips
- Slowly and clearly lead the weight change after the “testing the waters” - it is easily missed

Bonus!
Define traspie: three steps instead of one in the same timing, resulting in a double-time
graduationRequirements: Can they define traspie?
Can they do both the leaders' and follower's movement alone in the correct rhythm?
When leading, do they interrupt the open step before the follower has shifted fully?
When following, do they perceive the interruption of the open step when it is invited?

lessons.title: Embrace Breath
lessons.synopsis: Embrace and synchonize breathing with steps (inhale=pause, exhale=step) as you do the first two figures.
lessons.instructions:
To warm up, improvise for half a song with no embrace, then switch roles for the other half.

Walking side-by-side, one person sets pace and both pause on inhale, walk on exhale.

Same thing, this time try to extend the exhale by taking more steps.

Switch who’s setting the pace and do 3-4 again.

Review the First Figure. In practice hold, using just this material, let every shared inhale be a pause and every shared exhale be movement.

Switch roles.
graduationRequirements: Did they improvise at least half a song in each role with no embrace?
Were they able to synchronize inhale with pause and exhale with walk while walking side by side in each role?
Were they able do the First Figure, synchronizing inhale with pause and exhale with stepping, in each role?

lessons.title: Ronda Rocks
lessons.synopsis: How to enter the dance floor by making eye contact with other leaders, and using rocks to navigate
lessons.instructions:
1. Introduce counterclockwise line of dance with concentric lanes

2. Demonstrate entering the dance floor: eye contact with leader, enter in front (If there isn't a real ronda going, role-play: you pretend to be a leader dancing with an imaginary follower, they pretend to be a leader about to enter the dance floor with an imaginary follower.)

3. Have them practice: Enter floor, take embrace, lead the cross, then stop/exit and try again.

4. Review Tango Sentence

5. Show, by leading them, that any of the steps in this combination can be rocked.

6. Lead them through the ronda using the Tango Sentence in an embrace, rocking anytime you need to to avoid the tailgating the leader you're following. Narrate what you're doing as you do it.

7. Have them practice rocking each step in the Tango Sentence.

8. Have them lead you through the ronda in an embrace using the Tango Sentence, using rocks whenever needed to avoid tailgating.

Tips

- To rock a step, lower a little while mid-stride and

- Helps to think of dancing space as Monopoly board we travel counterclockwise

- Goal is to travel from one CORNER directly to another CORNER

- Leader's focus is FOLLOWING the couple in front
graduationRequirements: When leading can they rock any step in the Tango Sentence?
When following can they perceive and match the leader's invitations for rocking any step in the Tango Sentence?
Can they define the ronda and explain line of dance?
Did they practice entering the dance floor as a leader by using the leader's cabeceo?

lessons.title: On-The-Body [Apilado]
lessons.synopsis: How to hold your partner with firm connection between the torsos ("on-the-body"), and how to maintain this while moving
lessons.instructions:
1. Both stand upright, solo, chin low, neck long.

2. Move weight toward fronts of feet, then back.

3. Now stand facing frontally and do the same thing finding contact at follower's sternum (no arms). (Turn noses to left to accommodate!)

4. Explore different tones: Find a 1 on a scale from 1 to 10, a 10, a 5. 

5. Calibrate to a 4.

6. Maintain #4 tone while doing weight changes, side steps.

7. Find a different number, like #7, sync up and do side steps.

8. Add arms and keep focus on contact between upper bodies

9. Switch roles.

Tips
- Do this in an out-of-the-way spot

- Keep knees and lower body joints soft

- Should be able to callibrate from 1-7 without moving feet. Moving feet further from partner gets you 8, 9, 10.

- Stop anytime you feel tight or tense. Rest, breathe, stretch, smile

- If they bend forward awkwardly, or collapse their chest inward, reboot! Start over.

- Definition: Tone is the intensity of presence toward each other (could be called density, pressure or "pushing")
Beginners usually feel shy to push "hard." Encourage them with images: "like you're a bulldozer;" "try to push right through me"

- If both are women, lightly acknowledge "boob issue;" once addressed you'll find it doesn't interfere with exercise.

Bonus!

Try it with eyes closed!

Send thoughts of happiness and well-being to yourself and your partner

Synchronize breathing
graduationRequirements: Were they able to maintain Alignment while callibrating different intensities of presence?
Did they try a few different intensities of presence while doing weight changes and side steps in both roles?
Did they find a mutually comfortable amount of presence?
Were they able to maintain connection through the torsos, add the embrace, and do weight changes and steps?

lessons.title: Open/Close
lessons.synopsis: How to transition from being close to opening up, and back to close
lessons.instructions:
1. Show opening the embrace on a backward ocho to parada

2. Show closing the embrace on a side step (leader comes to follower)

3. Show another way of opening the embrace, at the cross from crossed system (leader takes shorter step)

4. Practice both these ways

5. Switch roles.

Tips

When opening up on the backward ocho, the follower rolls her upper body across the embrace: point of contact moves from sternum-to-sternum, across closer to side so there is more of a v-shape

The follower's arms need to be mobile and allow distance to change

Bonus!

Three Distances: Can you lead the difference between opening to basketball distance, baseball distance, vs ping-pong ball distance?

lessons.title: Inline Walking (Caminar)
lessons.synopsis: The goal of this mission is walking inline in close embrace. You might think that this is so basic and elementary that it should be one of the first missions. However, it actually takes a lot of technique (clearly invited and perceived back extensions), which is why it is a level 4 mission -- and one you will probably be refining your whole tango life!
lessons.instructions:
1. Warm up with extensions. In practice embrace, follower extends backwards, returns. Leader shadows, matches.

2. Now leader invites extension without moving his feet. Hint: solar plexus!

3. Once the extension feels like it's being clearly communicated, the leader shadows and matches with free leg.

4. Repeat 1-2 in a close embace.

5. Now lead 2 steps inline, then side step. Repeat - this cycles the starting foot. Do this for about half a song.

6. Try 4 steps inline.

Tips

- Good moment to review Extension - stretching leg w/o placing weight

- For a backwards extension, it helps to focus on stretching the free leg's knee and foot as far away from base leg as possible, without moving the base leg at all

- When leading 2 or 4 steps in a row inline, be sure you lead BOTH extensions, not just the first one.

- Every step needs an extension to be shared before the weight transfer begins.

- For this one it can help to switch roles really often

Bonus!

Ready for a challenge? Lead/follow a circle with free legs before 1st step! Downstream, out, upstream, GO!

Note: The foot circles in the video are an EXTRA CHALLENGE BONUS. They are not the meat of the mission. Have fun!

lessons.title: Come & Go [Vaiven]
lessons.synopsis: Combining inline steps with changes of weight - harder than it looks - requires perception, attention, technique. Many variants!
lessons.instructions:
1. In practice hold, lead them: Inline advancing, weight change, inline retreating, weight change.

2. Once it's working, do it in a on-the-body (no arms)

3. Then add arms, the full yummy embrace

4. Lead, interleaving with other elements, like Walking Inline or any Cross.

5. Have them lead it slowly and carefully in practice hold

6. When that's working, add the embrace

7. Have them interleave it with other elements and improvise.

Tips

- Easiest to start with leader's left, follower's right (handwards side)

- Be sure hips are facing hips at beginning (Frontality!)

- Do it REAL slowly the first several times
When follower or leader steps forward, landing heels first works best

Bonus!

Tons of variations on this one!

Try the other side: starting on hugward side

Change the size: advancing bigger, retreating smaller

Make the whole thing rotate counterclockwise, clockwise

Play with rhythm - hardest but soo good! Mmm syncopation!

Instead of advance/retreat, try 2x advance
Try 2x retreat - deal with navigation puzzle!

Make one of the steps outside-partner instead of inline

Layer these variations and use this element for a WHOLE SONG.

lessons.title: Rock Step Open
lessons.synopsis: Super useful rhythmic element for close embrace navigating
lessons.instructions:
1. Lead it slowly in practice hold (Advance inline, retreat inline, shared side step, weight change)

2. Now, lead so the side step lands a little more than 90° from original step. Can you get around 360° after 3 repetitions? 2?

3. Add double time rhythm: 123, 1
On-the-body contact but no arms, calibrate to #6 or what's comfortable and do the move

4. Add embrace

5. Switch roles, same progression (practice hold, add turning, add rhythm, on-the-body no arms, add embrace)

Tips

Lower a little to communicate rock

Don't transfer weight completely if you want to rock back

Be sure you really share the final weight change, it's easy to miss

Bonus!

Add a LOOONG pause before final weight change

lessons.title: Crossed Salida
lessons.synopsis: The best way to the cross in close embrace
lessons.instructions:
1. Do crossed salida (from "The Other System" mission) slowly in practice hold.

2. Do secret weight change on double-time

3. Once that's working, lead follower's cross on double-time

4. Now lead with on-the-body contact (no arms) with continuous tone

5. Add arms/embrace

6. Switch roles

Tips

- When first doing it on-the-body, calibrate to 7-8

- Helps if leader makes two BIG CLEAR BRAVE steps Left, Right to the cross, "VaVoom!" It can help to think of making the two steps into a single large gestute.

- There is a tendency for the leader to swallow the 2nd step on the way to the cross. This might happen because they aren't sure where the follower's feet are. If they hesitate, help them pause and try to perceive the follower's body through back arm and points of contact.

- Have leader say "cross" and pause when they feel the follower cross.

Bonus!

Graft it onto the end of Rock-Step-Open, using side step of Rock-Step-Open as 1st step of Crossed Salida
Explain why it's preferred way of going to cross in close embrace (easier to stay close)

lessons.title: Ocho Cortado
lessons.synopsis: The oldest move in the book that never gets old
lessons.instructions:
1. Review the cross that they already know

2. Explain that this is similar BUT instead of crossing from a back extension, follower crosses from an open step

3. Help them do the weirdest part for follower: stand split weight in open step, pivot right leg inward, sucking the left leg into the cross

4. Help them do the entire follower's footwork solo

5. Take a practice hold and lead them in it

6. Lead with on-the-body contact with continuous tone, no arms

7. Add embrace and repeat til it's pretty consistent

8. Interleave with Rock-Step-Open to practice improvising

9. Help them practice isolating turning ribcage. Hold their hips still as they open right, left.

10. In practice hold sync this ribcage opening/closing to follower's open, cross.

11. Help them lead it in practice hold

12. Have them practice-lead it on-the-body with embrace

13. Have them interleave it with Rock-Step-Open

Tips

- When first doing it on-the-body, calibrate to 7-8

- Be sure the follower commits weight in the cross. Leader has to turn enough, follower has to be ready!

- Leader's feet can stay very close to each other overall

- When leading, leader needs to clear legs out of space follower wants to walk into. Have them figure out where to put legs.

- Helps to hold leader's hips while they practice turning ribcage to right, left. Sync this to follower's open, cross.

- Watch out! If leader opens ribcage too much, follower turns too far

- Think of final step as a turning a little to leader's left

Bonus!

Tap the rhythm: 123 PAUSE 123. Try to dance it in this rhythm!

Find a more linear version and also a more circular version.

Follower embellishments: ankle-touches, heel-flex

Can you lead the whole thing without leader moving feet??

lessons.title: Milonguero Turn
lessons.synopsis: An enjoyable compact turn for a small crowded dance floor
lessons.instructions:
1. Lead Crossed Salida practice hold.

2. Lead it making it curl to the left. So cross ends up behind you

3. Do with on-the-body contact with continuous tone, no arms

4. Add embrace and repeat til it's pretty consistent

5. Lead half a song, interleaving with Crossed Salida

6. Help them lead it: in a practice hold, have them feel you (the follower) walk through it as they notice and name what you do

7. Have them lead it with a close embrace
Have them lead it, interleaving with Crossed Salida

Tips

- The milonguero turn is just the follower curling the walk to the cross

- Remember! Leader's footwork doesn't matter much, stay focused on follower's pattern

- When they lead, see what footwork they do naturally and help troubleshoot if legs in way

- Leader needs to do the same ribcage isolation as ocho cortado to get the cross

Bonus!

Figure out the transition that allows you to loop the turn (lead it over and over again)

Interleave with Crossed Salida, Rock Step Open, Ocho Cortado and create your Milonguero Groove!

Alternate entrance: Go to the cross, receive travelling forward ocho in crossed system, and rock it back, making this back step the first step of a gentle turn.

lessons.title: The Dark Side
lessons.synopsis: Comfortable unusual walk on closed side of the embrace
lessons.instructions:
1. In practice hold, show how it feels to follow when leader walks on closed side of embrace

2. Lead in close embrace

3. Help them see how it works as a leader in practice hold: -- Make a shared side step handward -- Secret weight change for leader -- Advance with free (left) leg on hugward ("dark") side -- Take one more step on dark side (leader's right leg), receiving backward ocho -- Take next step on light side, receiving second backward ocho and continue to the cross

4. Have them lead it with on-the-body contact with continuous tone

5. Have them lead it, interleaving it with Tango Sentence.

Tips

- Remind them to let their spine spiral toward leader when following

- Helps if leader lands in side step with hips (and toes) angled inward direction toward dark side

- Helps if leaders side-step-setup is a bit smaller than follower's

- Do it slowly in practice hold a lot of times. This move holds danger for follower's toes if rushed into close embrace

Bonus!

Explore why walking on dark side doesn't auto-cross (hint: embrace and line of dance!)

Find a few different entrances into dark side walking

Find a few more exits from dark side walking

Puzzle: Figure out how to get from Dark Side directly to Milonguero Turn!

lessons.title: Follower's Tuck
lessons.synopsis: Super useful cute tiny back tuck or mini-"volcada"
lessons.instructions:
1. Help them do the follower's tuck solo a few times to warm up

2. Distingush tuck from a pivot-ocho, and have them do both

3. Have them feel and follow your lead as you invite each part distinctly and very slowly: -- the back extension from left-footed travelling crossed system ocho -- the tuck ("plop!") -- the untuck

4. Lead it several times in close embrace
Lead, interleaving with previous missions in this ring.

5. Help them stumble-through it as a leader in practice hold: They go into crossed system and take (very small!) first step on left side (open side), lead the back extension, tuck, and untuck, then walk out in crossed system to the cross

6. Once it's clear, have them lead it in close embrace

7. Have them lead, interleaving with previous missions in this ring.

Tips

- Think of the tuck as a backward cross. It's complete when the weight is transferred, not before!

- When leading it, it really helps to get where you can see the follower's legs in the mirror!

- Helps if lead sets up with small ocho, keep weight on both legs, lead extension from belly

- To get tuck, use embrace to move her ribcage toward your armpit

- It is like starting to fall for the follower. Extended leg catches balance on other side of foot

- Leader needs to be ready to receive some of follower's weight!

- To lead untuck: leader brings belly button toward spine

Bonus!

Try it on the other side!

Find it from parallel system. Hint - the leader gets to cross!

Try to double up - lead two tucks in a row (fall right, fall left)

lessons.title: Milonguero Dip
lessons.synopsis: Ultra-dynamic swirly finish for compact left turn
lessons.instructions:
1. Lead and follow the Milonguero Turn several times to review

2. Walkthrough follower's part of Dip: milonguero turn where follower's cross is replaced by little forward step plus big pivot and final forward ocho

3. Lead the Dip slowly in practice hold ending with receiving forwards ocho

4. Lead it a few times in close embrace til it's working fluidly

5. Lead them interleaving with previous missions in ring.

6. Help them do leader's two-footed pivot: from open stance, pivots left on both feet & brings knees together

7. Give them specific leader's footwork: When follower steps side, leader extends side in opposite direction, then does two-footed pivot (that should cause her to pivot a lot upon full weight transfer)

8. Help them lead it a few times in practice hold so they feel how the parts connect

9. Have them lead it on-the-body

10. Have them lead it, interleaving with previous missions in this ring

Tips

- It helps to lower after the follower's side step

- The embrace needs to "roll" at the end of this move. "Rolling" means that the point of shared contact between the upper bodies moves from one side to the other. Explore when, where, and how.

Bonus!

Add two tap embellishment for follower: once before big pivot, once after

New ending: cortado open/close!

lessons.title: Classic Hugward
lessons.synopsis: Intro to fancy-pants tango turns
lessons.instructions:
1. Explain follower's grapevine default

2. Help them walk through follower's part from cross in practice hold: forward, side, back, ending with parada/pasada

3. Lead a few times til it's smooth

4. Interleave with other elements, alternate between leading turn vs repeated forward ochos

5. Now with embrace: Start in close embrace, open to ping-pong-ball distance at the cross, lead the turn, return to close embrace

6. Have the do the swivelly leader's footwork solo

7. Help them walk through the leader's part of the turn slowly, talk them through it in practice hold

> After cross, as leader invites forward ocho, steps with left foot opposite direction to follower's forward step

> As he leads side step, he swivels to find sacada with right

> Switch feet to parada her back stepNow have them lead it with the embrace described above

Tips

- Most followers will want to do a second forward ocho, out of habit, instead of the grapevine turn. Paying closer, more detailed attention to the invitation as follower makes that first ocho helps in both roles...

- Make sure leader still leads the cross. Once they start focusing on turn, it can go out the window

Bonus!

In the original turn, find the parada with leader's the other (left) foot. What system is this?

Try the turn with leader's other foot (right, left). How do you get to the parada now?

Help them see how walking to the cross is a grapevine variant

lessons.title: Classic Handward
lessons.synopsis: Flowy way to turn big out of ochos. Lapiz is BONUS, nonessential!
lessons.instructions:
1. Help them walk through follower's part: backwards ochos into back, side, forward.

2. Lead them a few times in practice hold (ending with parada of forward step).

3. Lead it in ping-pong-ball embrace.

4. Inteleave with other elements, like Dark Side and Paraday Play.

5. Help them do the leader's inward pivot that sets up the turn.

6. They lead it a few times in slow motion, gradually increasing the speed.

7. They lead with the embrace a few times.

8. Now they can interleave with those other elements mentioned above.

Tips

- Helps for follower's back-side-forward to be boxy, like a square horseshoe (vs "round") and to use her side step to get to other side of leader's body

- Have them lead ochos in slow motion and tell them exactly when to pivot inward for the turn (after she's cleared the ocho)

- Leader to support follower through big back pivot, support and give it time

- As follower lands in forward step at end of turn, leader lowers - to invite a pivot.

Bonus!

Try adding a lapiz during the follower's back-side-front

Introduce the concept of laterality (turning leader's side to the follower to invite a turn)

lessons.title: First Full Turn [Full Turn Handward]
lessons.synopsis: The first full turn is surprisingly easy
lessons.instructions:
1. Help them walk through follower's part: full turn starts & ends with forward

2. Show "americano" where both do big forward ocho

3. Lead them in the turn a few times

4. Help them do the leader's footwork: Pivot-cross inward left over right, pivot a lot (270 degrees?) while crossed, final tiny step (or weight change) with right foot

5. Help them walk through the turn in practice hold slowly, experiencing how the leader's footwork functions to support invitations for the follower

6. Have them do it normal speed a few times

7. Have them try it with close embrace -- how close can we stay?

8. Have them lead it, interleaving it with the previous 2 turns.

Tips

- Turning landing feet out in open step can help it really flow easily to americano ("fauxcho")

- In "americano," leader's step can be a bit smaller than follower's

- Remind follower to stay close to leader. (Side step tends to fall out of orbit)

- That first sacada gets "revealed" when the leader invites the follower into a big enough side step around him handward

- During all the pivoting of the turn, it helps the leader to keep a little weight in both feet

- Remind leader to keep opening/inviting with left side of embrace (instead of squashing left arm in)

Bonus!

Find a variation with different leader's footwork

BETTER ENDING THAN VIDEO: Instead of leader making a forward step, leader can change weight in place. Finish with shared side step.

lessons.title: The Barrida
lessons.synopsis: Foot drag surprise variation on backward ocho
lessons.instructions:
1. Practice isolation of right leg: from extended backwards to extended forwards and vice versa.

2. Lead the barrida slowly in practice hold. -- Switch to crossed system and then lower to pause both with legs split-weight -- Pivot to make sure your (leader's) hips are facing barrida destination -- Touch follower's forward foot with leader's knee on outside of her knee -- Invite follower's weight back, til front leg is free -- Drag front leg until it is in a full backward extension -- End with parada/pasada to forward ochos

3. Lead it in a comfortable close embrace.
Interleave it with Backwards Ochos, Parada Play, Classic Handward.

4. Help them through the leader's footwork: talk and walk through it in practice hold

5. Have them lead it a few times practice hold

6. They lead in close embrace

7. They interleave with other elements.

Tips

- When follower feels foot contact, push back into it, like velcro!

- Leader crosses follower's ankle when he catches the foot

- Leader needs to turn hips away from follower toward the barrida's destination.

Bonus!

Add leader's decoration after the parada! (see video)

Put the barrida in the context of the grapevine turn. Explore: which steps of the turn does it use?

Find a barrida that ends in the Cross.

Find a barrida with the other leg.

Puzzle: Where in the grapevine can a barrida happen?

Puzzle: How many barridas can you find?

lessons.title: The Pugliese Turn
lessons.synopsis: The infinite turn
lessons.instructions:
1. Lead them in the Classic Hugward a couple times.

2. Follow them in the Classic Hugward a couple times.

3. Explain this adds 1 more grapevine cycle to the Classic Hugward.

4. Have them do the follower's footwork: F, O, B, O, F, O, B.

5. Lead the turn several times. It ends with parada-pasada.

6. Lead them, interleaving with other turns and ochos.

7. Show them leader's setup: crossing left foot over right then pivoting on both feet ending in right foot over left with back left foot free. They will need to practice it a bunch of times solo.

8. Have them lead it slowly in practice hold several times, seeing how and when invitations are supported by footwork.

9. Have them lead it in a ping-pong-ball embrace.

10. Have them lead, interleaving it with other turns and ochos.

Tips

- Follower gotta focus and stay with leader…especially in back and side steps!

- Helps to think of this as a boxy horseshoe (vs a circle) where side steps takes follow to other side of leader's body.

- Follower uses strong legs to push herself to the next step and keep energizing the turn, supporting the leader's balance

- It helps for leader to practice that leader's swivel-thing many times

Bonus!

How many times in a row can you repeat?

Can you find different leader's footwork?

Do the Pugliese turn to the left. How would you enter it?

Enter the turn on a side step.

Enter the turn on a backward step.

lessons.title: Contraboléo
lessons.synopsis: Big ole gorgeous boléos finally!
lessons.instructions:
1. First help them do back boleos solo at mirror/wall out of solo backward ochos.

2. Lead travelling backwards ochos followed by boleo of left extension in slow motion

3. Do it more times until it becomes smooth

4. Have them lead backward ochos

5. Have them pause when follower is fully extended towards handwards side, before weight transfer

6. Show them how to interrupt the ocho and create boleo by stepping to where follower's foot has extended to

7. End with double forward ocho ("americano")

Tips

- When soloing, make sure follower keeps Alignment

- Follower needs to extend ocho-ing leg fully before transferring

- Timing is everything for lead. Must land boleo before follower starts to transfer weight.

- When they are leading, help them keep focus on follower's balance (=standing leg)

- On step that triggers the boleo, leader's hips should be facing follower

- Leader will tend to tug left side backwards away from follower to create boleo. Instead, keep it "surrounding" the follower.

- Leader needs to fully step onto leg to create boleo

Bonus!

End with an open-to-open sacada after the "americano"

Follower can bend knee, at end of full extension when they feel impulse of boleo!

lessons.title: Lapiz/Enrosque
lessons.synopsis: Making the leader's free leg pretty in the turn
lessons.instructions:
1. Have them walk through the follower's part: F, O, B, O, F handward

2. Lead them in the turn a few times in practice hold

3. Lead them in it using as close of an embrace as you can

4. Interleave it with a few other turns for half a song

5. Have them practice the leader's new, weird pivot-back-tuck-pivot-lapiz thingy solo

6. Roughdraft the leader's part in practice hold: -- After follower's forward ocho, as she steps side, leader pivots left foot left and tucks right foot back behind left -- Leader pivots on left front foot, with legs crossed tight, to show right side of body to follower -- Leader transfers weight to right back foot as follower transitions from side to back -- Lapiz with left during follower's back-side-forward -- End with a parada of forward ocho

7. Have them lead it in a "real" embrace

8. Have them interleave it with other turning elements

Tips

- Follower's focus: helping leader stay balanced

- Also helps if follower stays really active and helps the turn unfold by using each standing leg to "motorize" the turn

Bonus!

Find a different exit! Try multiple forward ochos.

Definions! lapiz: pencil. Usually lapices happen during follower's back-side-forward.

courses.title: Tango and I
courses.description: Sabine will take on the tango peer to peer learning...

lessons.title: Crossing Game
lessons.synopsis: followers forward cruzada and leaders backward cruzada and vice versa
lessons.instructions:
NOTE: -In practice embrace - 
1. Mentor starts in leadership role: the first 3 steps of the 8 count basic in parallel. (only to start the exercise)
2. Mentor takes 2 steps forward (starts on step 3 then 4) and crosses right leg behind left. 
2. Mentee takes 2 steps backward and crosses left over right (the cross/cruzada)     
3. Then Mentor goes forward and Mentee goes backward and they repeat the crosses over and over.

TIP: Notice the lenght of steps your partner takes and adjust.  
Keep stepping relatively close to one another.

FIGURE OUT: which step is a crossed step (either backward or forward) and which one an open step and why?
graduationRequirements: are you waiting for your partner to find alignment before you take the next step?
Do you have frontality at all times?
Are both knees soft (bend) when the cruzada/cross occurs?
Does the embrace stay flexible?

lessons.title: close to open embrace (love that hug)
lessons.synopsis: what do the arms do in an embrace? how do I hold a hug without holding back?
lessons.instructions:
1. face each other in a large open embrace -
2.Mentor: lead a sidestep to either left or right -
leader sidestep must step close to followers allignment -
3.gradually change the embrace by sliding arms on hugside and adjusting elbows handside
4. Play with alternating coming close or apart at different times.
5. Add a side rock step before you step to the side. 
6. Switch roles.

Note: the leader "pushes" away the standing leg to notify to the follower they need to extend their leg
graduationRequirements: can the follower slide their hugward arm easily around and back out the embrace
does the leader adjust the handheld side to accomodate the size of the embrace
is the alligment stabile for both parties
is there a flow for the adjusting of the embrace
When following do you extend your leg before you step?
When you lead the rockstep does the follower understand on time that it will not be a full step to the side?

lessons.title: Pivot this game
lessons.synopsis: how to swivel
lessons.instructions:
1. Mentor is "the wall"  holding out arms for stability + stepping side to side to accomodate the "pivoter"
2. the pivoter will take one forward cross - swivel, find allignment, and take another forward cross
3. the pivoter makes sure they swivel/pivot enough so not to cross the feet (no "duck feet")before they do propel forward.
4. the pivoter looks for frontality

NOTE: Adjust the embrace for comfort, grace, stability.

TIP: When you accomodate the pivoter, make sure they are initiating the move themselves i.e. listen carefully

BONUS: Why is this called a forward ocho?  ( hint: crossteps? and shape)
graduationRequirements: the pivoter finds alligment after the pivot before they step
the pivoter finds frontality
the pivoter turns out feet enough right after pivot so they can step without disrupting allignment

lessons.title: The forward ocho
lessons.synopsis: forward crosses in parallel system
lessons.instructions:
1. Leader goes to step #5 in 8 count basic and instead of feet together, the lead crosses right foot behind left foot ( like in the crossing game)
2. Follower finds alignment in their cruzada/cross by adjusting their embrace
3.  Leader steps back with their left leg while
4. follower steps forward (outside partner) with their right and finds frontality
5. Leader changes weight to right leg while follower does 1 forward cross + pivot and finds frontality.
6. Finish 8 count basic
graduationRequirements: Does leader accomodate the allignment for follower in step#5?
Is follower alligned by loosening up the embrace in step#5
Does leader wait with backward step untill follower is ready(alligned)
Does leader wait with shifting weight to right foot until follower has pivoted?
does follower pivot and have frontality?
Are you finding stillness right after the forward ochos are completed?

lessons.title: Let's play now
lessons.synopsis: combining all the element together
lessons.instructions:
1. Leader will combine: 6 count basic, 8 count basic, 8 count basic with forward ocho, rocksteps forward and side.
2. Follower will find alligment by adjusting their embrace accordingly
3. follower will find frontality by measuring their steps

Note:  Leader will endevour to be musical by adding quicker and slower motions
Note: Follower will endevour to be musical by extending their legs to the beat
graduationRequirements: Does the leader lead 6 count basic?
the 8 count basic?
the 8 count basic with forward ochos?
rocksteps?
adds stillness?
Adds quicker movements?
Does the follower find their own alligment?
adjust the embrace?
Steps close to the leader?
pivots before they step?
extend their legs when lead into a different direction?

lessons.title: Serving Champagne
lessons.synopsis: How to move your upperbody seperately from you lower body AND keep the integrity of followership and leadership
lessons.instructions:
As mentor: show the movement first. Then watch if *the elbows stay in front of the body * there is alignment * hips, knees, toes keep frontality...... 
 
1. The server of champagne has the elbows in front of the body
2. while toes-knees-hips point into the direction of the partner - the upper body moves from left to right. 
3. The partner makes sure that elbows stay in front of the body while lowerbody is stabile
4. find your boundaries: always making sure you turn upperbody without compromising your alignment ( NO bending the side of your body)
5. Another way of finding your boundaries is for your partner to softly turn you and you stop your partner before you might compromise your spine.

Tip: This movement is not a "soft" movement.... You really need to feel your core muscles engage when you turn upperbody. WHY? because THAT is the lead!!
graduationRequirements: Does the champagne stay on the tray when it is served left and right? ( do elbows stay in front of the body?)
are you on your left leg while your upperbody moves to the right and visa versa?
Are you in alignment?

lessons.title: Pivot while drinking the champagne
lessons.synopsis: Backward cross AND adding a pivot, all the while stay in alignment.
lessons.instructions:
1. Backward ochos...... In open embrace: 
while leader is the server of champagne , which will signal the follower to pivot.
2. Follower will add backward cross step and a pivot followed by another backward cross step. 
3. Leader makes sure to follow the follower when they take the step (for this exercise! So they can feel their own movements)

Note: the follower is responsible to step close to the leader ( almost under their own elbows) 
Note: watch frontality closely for both leader and follower
graduationRequirements: is the follower able to pivot without falling backward (pivot before you step)
Does the follower find frontality
Is there an extension before the step?
Is the follower stepping close to the leader? (under their elbow)
Is the leader keeping frontality?
Does the leader wait/listen for the follower to find their balance/alignment before they step?

lessons.title: Kindness of the embrace
lessons.synopsis: We are not all created equal: the embrace adjusts.....ALL THE TIME!
lessons.instructions:
1. stand toe to toe and assume the embrace - get comfortable with each other without moving at all.
2. the follower moves "inside" the embrace: either their left side against the leaders body, or turn the right side agains the leaders body. (only a light touch is needed )Leader accomodates the embrace accordingly.
3. Follower slides the left arm around the leaders right arm and shoulderblade (or lower)  Leaders accomodate their right arm moving it closer and bending and opening the elbow
4. Leader take note: your right arm moves to accomodate breast hight! 

Note: You should feel comfortable (alignment) at all times. No squeezing allowed.  
Feel a straight spine, arching your back will be uncomfortable.
graduationRequirements: Is leader moving their left arm and elbow?
Is leader accomodating the right arm to allow for space across the chest area?
Is the follower adjusting their left arm - moving across the leaders arm and shoulderblade (or lower)
Are you in alignment

lessons.title: 8 count basic break up
lessons.synopsis: The 8 count basic AND the backward ochos combined
lessons.instructions:
1. lead and follow the 8 count basic.
2. Lead - after step #3  : serve champagne while follower to pivot on their left foot backward.
3. Lead - step backwards with left while follower steps backwards with right.
4. Lead - serve champagne again to lead follower to pivot while on their right foot.
5. Lead step forward with right leg while follow steps backward with left leg.
6. finish 8 count basic.

Tip: find frontality before you think about taking the next step

Note: wait for each other to find balance and alignment before taking the next step.
graduationRequirements: do you understand the choreography?
Are you "listening" to each others alignment before stepping?
Are you adjusting the embrace when there is a pivot present?
Are you finding frontality?

lessons.title: Let's play again...
lessons.synopsis: Putting together all the lessons
lessons.instructions:
*Lead the 8 count basic
*Lead the rock steps
*Lead the 8 count basic with the forward ocho
*Lead the 8 count basic with the backward ocho
*Lead the 8 count basic with both backward AND forward ocho. 
*Play and improvise
Follower, make sure you step to the music, find alignment, find frontality and extend the leg before you step into the direction of the lead.

Tip: find stillness frequently to adjust alignment and embrace.
graduationRequirements: Lead: did you improvise ALL the lessons
Did you find the beat to the music
Did you pivot before you stepped
Did you pause, speed up and stay in the line of dance?
Did you adjust your embrace?

lessons.title: Ice skating required to avoid the tightropewalker
lessons.synopsis: overcoming the odd sensation when you both start walking with the same leg (left/ right) - Crossed system
lessons.instructions:
1. In practice embrace both have full weight on your right leg.
2. The leader walks forward ( the left leg goes first) Leader "ice skates" - see video!
3. The follower walks backwards ( the left leg goes first) Follower "walks the tightrope" - see video!
4.  It's gonna feel pretty funny at first, keep checking if you are in Crossed System!!  If not, then simply start over: both of you weight on your right leg and walking with your left.

note: Leadership: make sure you collect everytime before you step
Followership: make sure you extend the leg first - remember to "carry the furniture down a flight of stairs backward"

Extra: Can you notice if there is a pivot? and at what precise moment does that happen?  Hint: think about the opposing shoulder position in crossed system.
graduationRequirements: Leadership: are you stepping when the follower is on their axis/alignment?
Leadership: are you collecting before every step?
Leadership: are you stepping on the beat of the music?
Followership: Are feeling the alignment before you extend the leg?
Followership: Are you feeling a pivot/swivel before you extend and step?
Bonus: can you explain why there is a pivot happening?

lessons.title: Secrets in stepping together apart.
lessons.synopsis: How to get in and out of crossed system and parallel system
lessons.instructions:
*What is crossed system? Both partners start with the right leg or both with the left leg.
*What is parallel system? One partner starts with the left leg while the other one starts with their right leg. 

1. Second step of the 8 count, the leader changes their weight from their left to right - in place. (march in place quickly)
2. Follower you create awareness that you are now in crossed system, you stay on that right leg.
3. walk 4 to 6 steps in crossed system
4. Leader goes outside partner with their left and right leg.
5. Follower find frontality again - Cruzada/Cross ( left over right, the Cruzada is where the follower does a quick weight change) 
6. you are back in parallel system!
7. finish the 8 count basic with step number 6....7 and 8.   

NOTE step 7 and 8 ~ leader change your weigth at the top of the circle! (NO marching)  Take a look at the flex lesson: The half circle up , changing weight.
graduationRequirements: Does the follower feel like the systems have changed AND stays on the correct leg?
Is the leader able to change the weight in such a manner that the follower does not follow their body movement by changing their weight as well?
Is the follower going into the cruzada with either a quick quick OR a slow cruzada?
Does the follower extend the legs far enough so they end up in front of the leader when they execute the cruzada?
Does the leader stay with the follower when they go outside partner i.e. frontality?
Does the leader have a "flowing" left leg (kinda like a slower step forward) all the way to step #6 in the 8 count basic?

lessons.title: Time to play with the systems
lessons.synopsis: adding crossed system to our playlist
lessons.instructions:
*Leader will combine: 6 count basic, 8 count basic, 8 count basic with forward ocho, and backward ocho plus rocksteps
*Leader will add the 8 count basic in Crossed system AND walking in crossed system
*Leader will endevour to be musical by adding quicker and slower motions
*follower will find alligment by adjusting their embrace accordingly
*follower will find frontality by measuring their steps
*follower will endevour to be musical by extending their legs to the beat
*follower will adjust their embrace to maintain their alignment 

Note: line of dance - going around the room counter clock wise and staying away from the middle of the room
Note: start playing with dancing closer to one another.

Tip: listen to the music! When do you start and when do you stop/pause/stillness.
graduationRequirements: 8 count basic?
8 count basic in crossed system?
rocksteps?
forward ochos?
backward ochos?
Adjusting of the embrace to maintain alignment?
Line of dance?
Can explain the difference between parallel system and crossed system
Is experimenting with closed embrace?
when following stays in crossed system when lead there?

lessons.title: Drunken line
lessons.synopsis: The grapevine! Or a drunken sailors walk forward - open - backwards!
lessons.instructions:
1. Figure out the difference between the forward and backward cross:
Stop your step forward or backward right in the middle. (both feet are bearing weight) OKAY: in relationship to your partner are your legs crossed or open?  See video for clarity...  Words are tricky!

2.Right! You have figured out the difference between a forward cross and a backward cross - hooray!
NOW make a grapevine: forward x is followed by an open step and then a backward x etc. etc. (the Drunken line)

3. Same grapevine on a line needs a pivots to "glue" the steps together: 
Find a fixed point of frontality (a wall, or mirror)  
Start with a forward cross ( your fixed point is your pretend partner) ~ pivot ~ open step ~ pivot ~ backward cross ~ etc etc.

Tip: Frontality is key here, but your minor twist in your spine should NEVER hurt or feel uncomfortable. Remember to have relaxed shoulderblades and a straight spine.

Another tip: it helps to have your arms up and out in open embrace form: this way you can step (close) underneath your elbow.
graduationRequirements: Explain the difference between a crossed step and an open step
What is the sequence in a grapevine?
When is the pivot added?
How do you know where to step?

lessons.title: a square peg in a circle
lessons.synopsis: 4 fixed points, the square on the ground, can produce a lovely circular movement in the upperbody. Making a full turn around your partner.
lessons.instructions:
1. Mentor shows the 4 points on the ground [ ]  
2. In large practice embrace both partners start with a forward cross step. ( the middle of the square is frontality) followed by the open and back cross.

Mentor: YOU start and stop when needed!!

3. Notice when you need to pivot ( on the corners) 
4. Notice when you do NOT need to pivot and are facing each other in the open steps (upper AND lower body, including toes)
5. Try to keep stepping on the same corners.
6 Follow each others lead and alignment. 

Note: Make the square only as large as a comfortable step lenght.

Bonus!  Do you know if at any time it feels like the movement speeds up or slows down and why?  ( think about when you pivot and when do you not)
graduationRequirements: Are you able to start the square steps with your partner comfortably?
Are you able to keep your alignment/balance?
When preparing the backward cross, is your embrace adjusted to comfort level?
Are you pivoting before you step?
Can you comfortably stop the movements at any step?
Both directions??

lessons.title: Powerhouse Tango
lessons.synopsis: Dancing your best self, taking YOUR movement because you listened to your partner - Followers Power & Follow the Follower.
lessons.instructions:
1. Practice embrace
2. One partner takes the decision to walk forward with some exageration. Powerful forward steps. Other partner assumes the follower role and listens to when to extend backwards.
3. The person following finds a moment to "take over" the forward movement by defining them selves as the strong dancer they are: listen to where you can find a good entrance, "stand your ground" and start walking forward.
4. Switch back and forward in your leadership or followership role making sure you are not falling into a pattern of steps, vary the number of steps you take
5. Discuss what is happening physically when you decide to "take over" the lead and/or assume the followers role. 
6. Start again, this time try to find a flow.... who is leading and who is following when the moment arrives to change direction.
7. Discuss
8. Can you try the same with the molinette in a square box? (video)

Tip: walk heel to toe when you start walking forward.
One more tip: SLOW down the transfer or leadership, FEEL the changes in your body rather than rushing the movement.
graduationRequirements: Are you keeping your embrace soft/plyable when either leading or following?
Are you able to vary the size of your steps when walking forward?
Are you finding "flow" when switching lead and follow?

lessons.title: Winding up, Molinette, Full Turn
lessons.synopsis: One of the cornerstones in Argentine Tango: the molinette / the turn
lessons.instructions:
STAY IN PARALLEL SYSTEM! You change weight when your partner does.

Leadership:
1. Lead the follower to their forward ochos in parallel system.
2. Your Molinette starts when the follower is ready to take the forward cross in front of you. Remember to wait with changing your weight (half circle up movement - flex lesson) Until the follower is ready to take their step after they pivot....  
3. OKAY, your follower has pivoted, you now have 5 weight changes under your own axis left.     1=right foot together
                          2= left T behind right
                          3= right together
                          4= left T behind right
                          5= right foot together
5. Every time you step, you make sure you are aligned : your shoulder especially, and your embrace is soft.
6. Every time you step you look at your follower while you take frontality away with your body (the T step behind)
7. Let your follower step AHEAD of you.

Followership:
1. Make sure when you step you do so underneath your elbow. ( the steps are rather large)
2. PIVOT before you step
3. When prepping for the back cross, which can be tricky. As a follower step close to the leader ~ so under your/partners elbow ~ find the corner of the square - USE FOLLOWERS POWER 
4. In a full turn the follower has 8 actions ( where a step is an action AND a pivot is an action)  1= Forward cross
                               2= Pivot
                               3= Open step
                               4= Pivot
                               5= Backward cross
                               6= Open step
                               7= Forward cross
                               8= Pivot
5. Follower has to find frontality always!
6. Keep finding your alignment and comfort by adjusting the embrace to your standards. 

Note: it is normal for the pivot to slow down the rhythm of the turn. (Slow slow quick quick slow) Come find a facilitator to explain this to you! Extra points if you are able to figure this out on your own!
graduationRequirements: When leading are you waiting for the follower to step ahead of you? (when you start the turn)
When leading do you keep frontality in tact by looking at your follower and taking T steps?
When leading are you letting the follower come to you for frontality in the very last step of this turn? (followers forward x)
As a leader how many steps do you take in the turn?
As follower do you find your alignment EVERY time when you "hit" a corner of the turn?
As a follower are you able to step to the "imaginary" corners, even on the open steps and back cross?
As a follower how many actions do you have in the full turn (pivots and steps)
As a follower are you keeping frontality at all times?

lessons.title: Be the king of your own beat! (most of the times)
lessons.synopsis: Tango music and Tango dancing, goes hand in hand.....literally....
lessons.instructions:
Mentor: watch the video with your mentee, when doing the exercises, no need to partner up - solo movement works best. 
Headphones are a great option - or a more silent hallway perhaps? Or Ask the DJ to play Loco.

1. Listen and watch Juan D'Arienzo and his orchestra play Loco - see video link -
2. Close your eyes and listen to the music. Tap, sway, free move or find your stillness (if you dare) Just take it in.
3. One more time: watch the video and see what Juan D'Arienzo is showing you; how to listen (and dance) to his music. What is he highlighting? Which instrument(s)?   
4. Start moving to Loco, making sure you find the beat(s) with your steps, either large, small or medium. And quick or slow.
5. Start moving to Loco once more, and ONLY find the moments of stillness/pause and linger a lot longer in the stillness than you usually would do. 
6. Highlight the moments of stillness AND highlight the beats. Can you make sure you feel the difference deeply.

Tip: read a bit about Juan D'Arienzo. He is one of the cornerstones of Argentine Tango music. Known as the King of the Beat - El Rey del Compás -
graduationRequirements: Can you predict when the pauses will happen in the song?
When you find stillness, are you only on one foot?
Are you able to find the beginning of the musical sentence, is it distinct to you?
